It‚Äôs particularly helpful and increase readability to increasing the kerning when you have a heading or text in the sentences in uppercase . But if you have a heading or a text in the sense is normal case increasing or deceasing the kerning make it harder to read.

<html>
<head>
	<link href = "example.com"
				type = "text/css"
				rel  = "stylesheet"> </head> 
<body>
	<h1> Briards </h1>
		<h2> by Ivy Duckett </h2>
		<p> The <a href = "https://www.briard.com"> briard </a> or berger de brie , is a large breed 
		of dog traditionally used as a herder and guardian of sheep </p>
		<h1> Breed History </h1>
		<p> The briard which is believed to have originated in France, 
		has been bred for centuried
		to herdand to protect sheep. The breed was used by the 
		French Army as sentries, messengers
		and to search for wounded soldiers because of its 
		fine sense of hearing. Briards were used in 
		the First World War almost to the point of extinction. 
		Currently <span class = "credit"> the population of briards is
		slowly recovering charlemagne, napoleon, </span> 
		Thomas Jefferson and Lafayette all owned briards </p>
</body>
</html>
h1 
{
	text-tranform: uppercase;
	letter-spacing: 0.2em;
}

word-spacing

You can also change the gap between or control the space between the word also using the word-spacing property .

The value of these two property should be given as ems instead of pixels it will be add at the top of the default value specify by the fonts.

The default gap between is often around ( 0 .25 em ) and It‚Äôs unlikely that you wound need to change this property regularly. If the typeface is bold or you increase the space between the letter. Changing the gap between word can be applied here to increase readability . 

<html>
<head>
	<link href = "example.com"
				type = "text/css"
				rel  = "stylesheet"> </head> 
<body>
	<h1> Briards </h1>
		<h2> by Ivy Duckett </h2>
		<p> The <a href = "https://www.briard.com"> briard </a> or berger de brie , is a large breed 
		of dog traditionally used as a herder and guardian of sheep </p>
		<h1> Breed History </h1>
		<p> The briard which is believed to have originated in France, 
		has been bred for centuried
		to herdand to protect sheep. The breed was used by the 
		French Army as sentries, messengers
		and to search for wounded soldiers because of its 
		fine sense of hearing. Briards were used in 
		the First World War almost to the point of extinction. 
		Currently <span class = "credit"> the population of briards is
		slowly recovering charlemagne, napoleon, </span> 
		Thomas Jefferson and Lafayette all owned briards </p>
</body>
</html>
h2
{
	text-tranform: capitalize;
	word-spacing: 1em;
	font-weight: bold;
}

Alignment

text-align

The text-align property allow you to control the alignment of the text. This should take this following value :

left

This indicate that the text should be align to the left.

right

This indicate that the text should be align to the right.

center

This center the text.

justify

This indicate that every line in the paragraph except the last line. Should to be set to take up the full width of the containing box.

When you have several paragraph of text it‚Äôs consider easier to read when the text is left align.

Justify the text look the words on each every individual line and create a equal gaps between those words. It can look very odd if you end up with a larger gasp between some word and smaller gasp between some other. This is often happen when you have a line that are not very wide or a text that contain a long words. 

<html>
<head>
	<link href = "example.com"
				type = "text/css"
				rel  = "stylesheet"> </head> 
<body>
	<h1> Briards </h1>
		<h2> by Ivy Duckett </h2>
		<p> The <a href = "https://www.briard.com"> briard </a> or berger de brie , is a large breed 
		of dog traditionally used as a herder and guardian of sheep </p>
		<h1> Breed History </h1>
		<p> The briard which is believed to have originated in France, 
		has been bred for centuried
		to herdand to protect sheep. The breed was used by the 
		French Army as sentries, messengers
		and to search for wounded soldiers because of its 
		fine sense of hearing. Briards were used in 
		the First World War almost to the point of extinction. 
		Currently <span class = "credit"> the population of briards is
		slowly recovering charlemagne, napoleon, </span> 
		Thomas Jefferson and Lafayette all owned briards </p>
</body>
</html>
h1 
{
	text-align: left;
}
h2
{
	text-align: left;
}
.credit 
{
	text-align: center;
}
p 
{
	text-align: justify;
}

Vertical Alignment

vertical-align

A vertical-align property is the common source of confusion. It‚Äôs not intent to allow you to vertically-align the text in the middle of the block element such as <p> and <div> Although it also have the same effect when use with the table cell such as <th> , <td>

A vertical-align were commonly use with the inline element such as <em> , <img> , <strong> when use with this element it perform the task similar to the HTML align attribute that you met on page 103 - 106 . The value it can take :

  • baseline
  • sub
  • super
  • top
  • text-top
  • middle
  • bottom
  • text-bottom

It can also take the length ( usually specify in pixel and ems ) or a percentage of the line-height.

<head>
	<link href  = "example.csss"
				 rel  = "stylesheet"
				 type = "text/css"/> 
</head>
<body>
	<p>
	<img 
			 src    = "jcole.jpg"
			 alt    = "jcole"
			 title  = "jcole"
			 width  = "100"
			 height = "100" id = "img1"/> J cole </p>
	<br/>
	
	<p>
	<img
			 src    = "jcole.jpg"
			 alt    = "jcole"
			 title  = "jcole"
			 width  = "100"
			 height = "100" id = "img2"/> J cole </p>
	
	<br/>
	
	<p>	
	<img
			 src    = "jcole.jpg"
			 alt    = "jcole"
			 title  = "jcole"
			 width  = "100"
			 height = "100" id = "img3"/> J cole </p>


</body>
#img1
{
	verical-align: text-top;
}
#img2
{
	vertical-align: baseline;
}
#img3
{
	verical-align: text-bottom;
}

Indenting Text

text-indent

( indent mean to move something further or away from their position )

The text intent property allow you to indent the first line of the text within the element. The amount of line to be indent can be specific in the number of way but it usually given in pixels and ems.

It can take the negative value which mean that it can push the text to be off the browser main window. As you can see we using this technique on our example the <h1> element is using the background images represent the heading and the text has been move to the far left to remove it off the browser screen.

We will still want the text to be on the page for the search engine and people who use the screen reader that cant view the images. but we cannot let to to be display on top of the logo otherwise it will be unreadable. By setting it text indent to 9999pixel moving the text to the left to make it out of sight but it still i the HTML code.

The second indicate that every element got the class attribute and that class attribute have a value credit their text-indent set to 20px meaning that it will be move to the right .

We introduce the background images on the future chapter.

<html>
<head>
	<link href = "example.com"
				type = "text/css"
				rel  = "stylesheet"> </head> 
<body>
	<h1> Briards </h1>
		<h2> by Ivy Duckett </h2>
		<p> The <a href = "https://www.briard.com"> briard </a> or berger de brie , is a large breed 
		of dog traditionally used as a herder and guardian of sheep </p>
		<h1> Breed History </h1>
		<p> The briard which is believed to have originated in France, 
		has been bred for centuried
		to herdand to protect sheep. The breed was used by the 
		French Army as sentries, messengers
		and to search for wounded soldiers because of its 
		fine sense of hearing. Briards were used in 
		the First World War almost to the point of extinction. 
		Currently <span class = "credit"> the population of briards is
		slowly recovering charlemagne, napoleon, </span> 
		Thomas Jefferson and Lafayette all owned briards </p>
</body>
</html>
h1 
{
	text-indent: -9999px;
	background-images: url("images/logo");
}
.credit , h2
{
	text-indent: 20px;
}

CSS3 : Drop Shadow

text-shadow

text-shadow have been commonly use. Despite lacking support by in all the browser.

It is used to create a drop shadow that is the dark version of word just behind it and it slightly offset. It can also be use to create a embossed effect by adding the shadow that is slightly lighter than the text.

The value of this property can be quite complicate and it can take three value and a color for a drop shadow

  1. First value indicate how far the left and right the shadow should fall.
  1. Second value indicate the distance the top and bottom the shadow should fall.
  1. Third this is the optional value which indicate the amount blur should applied to the drop shadow.
  1. Fourth value specify the color of the drop shadow.

The text-shadow property were commonly popular but At the time of author writing this book this property is not support any version of the internet explorer. But Browser maker has start introduce this property such as Safari , Chrome , Opera , Google , Firefox .

	<html>
		<head>
			<link href = "example.css"
						rel  = "stylesheet"
						type = "text/css">
		</head>
		</body>
			<p id = "p1"> The briard is known as heart wrapped in fur. </p>
			<p id = "p2"> The briard is known as heart wrapped in fur. </p>
			<p id = "p3"> The briard is known as heart wrapped in fur. </p>
			<p id = "p4"> The briard is known as heart wrapped in fur. </p>
			<p id = "p5"> The briard is known as heart wrapped in fur. </p>
		</body>
	</html>
			
#p1 
{
	background-color: gray;
	text-shadow: 1px 2px 0px #000000;
	/* shadow fall to right(1px) , shadow fall to bottom(2px) */
}
#p2
{
	background-color: gray;
	text-shadow: -3px -4px 12px red;
	/* shadow fall to left(3px) , shadow fall to Top (4px) */
}
#p3 
{
	background-color: gray;
	text-shadow: 3px -1px 2px blue;
	/*  shadow fall to right(3px) , shadow fall to top(2px) */ 
}
#p4 
{
 background-color: gray;
 text-shadow: -3px 1px 2px white;
 /* shadow fall to left(3px) , shadow fall to bottom(1px) */
}
#p5
{
background-color: gray;
text-shadow: 3px 3px white;
/* shadow fall to left(3px) , shadow fall to bottom(3px) */
}

First Letter Or Line

:first-letter or :first-line

You can specify different value for the first letter and first line of text within the element. Using the

  • :first-letter
  • :first-line

Technically These are not a property they are known as pseudo-element.

You specify pseudo-element at the end of selector and you specify the decoration just like you would for other element.

CSS introduce both pseudo-element and pseudo-class. The pseudo-element act like their an extra element inside the code. So in the case of first-letter or first-line their an extra element around the selector which have it own style applied .

A pseudo-class act like an extra value for the class attribute. In the case of :visited ( which you see on next page ) allow users to have different style for link that have been visited. Similarly to :hover which allow you to style element differently when users hover over them. 

<html>
<head>
	<link href = "example.com"
				type = "text/css"
				rel  = "stylesheet"> </head> 
<body>
	<h1> Briards </h1>
		<h2> by Ivy Duckett </h2>
		<p> The <a href = "https://www.briard.com"> briard </a> or berger de brie , is a large breed 
		of dog traditionally used as a herder and guardian of sheep </p>
		<h1> Breed History </h1>
		<p> The briard which is believed to have originated in France, 
		has been bred for centuried
		to herdand to protect sheep. The breed was used by the 
		French Army as sentries, messengers
		and to search for wounded soldiers because of its 
		fine sense of hearing. Briards were used in 
		the First World War almost to the point of extinction. 
		Currently <span class = "credit"> the population of briards is
		slowly recovering charlemagne, napoleon, </span> 
		Thomas Jefferson and Lafayette all owned briards </p>
</body>
</html>
p:first-letter
{
	font-size: 100%;
}
p:first-line
{
	font-weight: bold;
}

Styling Links

:link and :visited

Browser tend to show the link in blue and an underline by default they are changing the color of the link when the link have been visited to help visitor visit your site know which page they have been to.

In CSS there are two pseudo classes they allow you to set different style for the link when they have been visit or not yet visit.

:link

Allow you to style the link that have not yet been visited .

:visited

Allow you to style the link that the users have click on it or when the users have visited that link.

They are more commonly use to control color of the link and whether it should appear underline or not.

As you see on your browser if you try example below on your browser you can see link that have been visited have appear in different color this help the visitor visit your site known which page that already seen.

Often , :hover and :active ( which talk on next page ) pseudo class are use to alter the appearence when the users hover over them or click on them .

<html>
	<head>
		<link href = "example.css"
					rel  = "stylesheet"
					type = "text/css"/></head>
		<body>
			<h1> Dog Breeds: B </h1>
			<ul>
				<li><a href = ""> Basset hound</a></li>
				<li><a href = ""> Beagle </a></li>
				<li><a href = ""> Bearded Collie </a></li>
				<li><a href = ""> Beauceron </a></li>
				<li><a href = ""> Bedlington Terrier </a></li>
				<li><a href = ""> Belgian Shepherd </a></li>
				<li><a href = ""> Bergamasco </a></li>
				<li><a href = ""> Bichon Frise </a></li>
				<li><a href = ""> Bloodhound </a></li>
				<li><a href = ""> Bolognese </a></li>
				<li><a href = ""> Border Collie </a></li>
				<li><a href = ""> Boder Terrier </a></li>
				<li><a href = ""> Borzoi </a></li>
				<li><a href = ""> Bouvier des Flandres </a></li>
				<li><a href = ""> Briard </a></li>
				<li><a href = ""> Bull Terrier </a></li>
				<li><a href = ""> Bulldog </a></li>
		</ul>
	</body>
</html>
li>a:link
{
	color: red;
	text-decoration:none;
}
li>a:visited
{
	color: blue;
	text-decoration: underline;
	letter-spacing: 0.2em;
}

Responding To User

There are Three pseudo-class that allow you to change the appearence of the element when users interact with them.

:hover

This applied when the users hovering over the element using the pointing device such as mouse. This has commonly use to change the appearence of the link and button when user place cursor over them. It‚Äôs worth noting that such event it‚Äôs doesn‚Äôt work with a touch screen device ( such as iPad ) because the screen not able to tell if someone hovering using their finger over the element.

:active

This applied when the element is activated by the users For example button being pressed or link being click. Sometimes this can be use to make the button or link to feel it likely to being press or click by changing the style and position of the element slightly.

:focus

This applied when the element is focus. Every element that users can interact with such as form control is focus.

Focus occur when browser discover that you are ready to interact with the element on the page. For example you place the cursor in the form input ready to Accept typing. This element is said to have focus so the :focus will be activated.

It‚Äôs also possible to use the tab key on your keyboard to move thought the Interactive item on the page When you use the pseudo-class. They should appear in order :link , :visit , :hover , :focus , :active. 

<html>
	<head>
		<link href = "example.css"
					type = "text/css"
					rel  = "stylesheet"/></head>
			<body>
				<form action = "example.php"
							method = "post">
								<input type = "text"
												name = "username"
												class = "username"
												placeholder = "Please Enter your usersname">											
												<br/>
							  <input type = "submit"
											  name = "Submit"
											  value = "Submit"
											  class = "submit"/> </form>
			</body>
	</html>							  
input.usersname:hover
{
	background-color: red;
}
input.username:focus
{
	background-color: blue;
}
input.usersname:active
{
	background-color: blue;
}
input.submit:hover
{
	background-color: red;
}
input.submit:focus
{
	background-color: blue;
}
input.submit:active
{
	background-color: blue;
}

Attributes Selectors

You met the most popular CSS selector on page 238. But there are the set of attribute selector that allow you to create a rule apply to an element that have a attribute with a specific value.

Existence

Match an specific attribute whatever the value.

[]
{
	
}

[class]
{

}

For example:

[class]
{
	text-transform: uppercase;
}
/* Target every element that got the class attribute no matter what the value */

[id]
{
	text-transform: lowercase;
}
/* Target very element that got the id attribute no matter what the value */


p[class]
{
	text-transform: capitalize;
}
/* Target every <p> element that got the class attribute */

Equality

Match an specific attribute with a specific value.

[=]
{

}
[class="value"]
{
}

For example:

[class = "header"]
{
	text-transform: uppercase;
}
/* target any element that have a class attribute and that class attribute have a value header */

[id = "footer"]
{
	text-transform: lowercase;
}
/* target any element that have a id attribute and that id attribute have a value footer */

div[id = "body"]
{
	text-transform: capitalize;
}
/* target <div> element that have a id attribute and that id attribute have a value body */

Space

Match an attribute whose value appear in a space-separate list of words. ( meaning that if the attribute got a value Arifin Depay Jr since Depay and Jr is separate by the space of word I assume I want to match that Depay or Jr word see example below ).

( case sensitive )

[~=]
{

}
[class~="value_that_separate_by_the_space"]
{
}

For example:

<div class = "Arifin Depay Jr"> Arifin </div>
<div id    = "Kanzaki"> Kanzaki </div> 
/* to target that element <div class = "Arifin Depay Jr"> Arifin </div> using the 
space selector we need to find the list of word separate by the space since 
Depay separate by the space and Jr separate by the space so we can use this space selector
to target this class */

[class ~= "Depay"]
{
	text-transform: uppercase;
}
/* target any element that have a class attribute and that class attribute have a value 
Depay separate by the space */ 
/* so this match the <div class = "Arifin Depay Jr"> Arifin </div> 
since Depay is the class attriubute value and seperate by space */

[class ~= "Jr"]
{
	text-transform: lowercase;
}
/* target any element that have a class attribute and that class attribute have a value
Jr separate by the space */
/* just like above it match <div class = "Arifin Depay Jr"> Arifin <div> since Jr is a 
value of the class attribute and seperate by the space */

[class ~= "Arifin"]
{
	text-tranform: capitalize;
}
/* same as above since Arifin is a class value and separate by the space */

[id ~= "Kanzaki"]
{
	color: red;
}
/* target any element that have a id attribute with a value Kanzaki separate by the 
space */
/* so it match the <div id = "Kanzaki"> Kanzaki </div> since it has the id attribute with
the value Kanzaki separate by the space */


[id ~= "Kan"]
{
	color: blue;
}
/* target any element that have a id attribute with a value Kan separate by the space */
/* so it doesnot match <div id = "Kanzaki"> kanzaki </div> 
since it only match the id attribute
with a word Kan separate by the space this id = "Kanzaki" 
the Kan does not separate by the 
space so it does not match */

Prefix

Match an specific attribute whose value is begin with specific string.

[^=]
{

}
[class^="value_of_the_attribute_start_with_a_string"]
{

}

For example:

[class ^= "dog"]
{
	text-size: 10em;
}
/* target any element that have a class attribute and that attribute have a value start 
with a string called "dog" */  
/* something like this <div class = "dog boss"> dog </div> *//* since class attribute 
start with a string call dog */

[class ^= "d"]
{
	text-transform: uppercase;
}
/* target any element that have a class attriubte and that attribute have a value start 
with a string call "d" */

[id ^= "da d"]
{
	text-tranfrom: lowercase;
}
/* target any element that have a class attribute and that attribute have a value start 
with a string call "da d" */

Substring

Match an attribute whose value contain in the specific substring.

[*=]
{
}
[class*="value_of_the_sub_string"]
{

}

For example:

[class *= "About"]
{
}
/* target any element that have a class attribute and that class attriubte have substring
"About" contain with within the value */

[class *= "f"]
{
}
/* target any element that have a class attribute and that class attribute have a substring 
"f" contain within the value */

Suffix

Match an attribute whose value at the end with specific string.

[$=]
{
}
[class$="value_of_the_attribute_with_the_string"]
{
}

For example:

[class$= "lord"]
{
	text-transform: uppercase;
} 
/* target any element that have a class attribute and that class attribute have a value
end with "lord" */
[class$= "g"]
{
	text-transform: lowercase;
}
/* target any element that have a class attribute and that class attribute have 
a value end with "g" */

Example Text

This example combines many of the technique shown in this chapter

The sized of fonts are controlled using the font-size property. The heading are changed from bold to normal using the font-weight property. We have also specific different choice of fonts using the font-family property.

The <h1> elements uses the CSS3 text-shadow property to create the drop shadow behind it. The <h2> elements is converted to uppercase using the text-transform property , and to make the uppercase text easier to read, we have increased the space between each letter using the letter-spacing property.

For the main body text, we have increased the line-height property so there is a bigger gap between each line of text, thereby making it easier to read. In the first paragraph, the first-line pseudo-elements allows us to style the first line of the introduction in bold. Finally the credit is italicized and align to the right-hand side of the page.

<!DOCTYPE html PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD XHTML 1.0 Strict//EN"
"https://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-strict.dtd">
	<html>
		<head>
			<link href = "example.css"
						type = "text/css"
						rel  = "stylesheet"/>
			<title> Example Text </title>
		</head>
		<body>
			<h1 id = "header"> Briards </h1>
			<h2 id = "sub header"> a heart wrapped in fur </h2>
			<p> The <a href = "https://www.briard.com"> briard </a>, or berger de brie, is a 
			large breed of dog traditionally used as a herder and guardian of sheep . <p>
			<h2 id = "subheader2"> breed history </h2>
			<p attr=""> The briard, which is believed to have originated in France, has been bred for 
			centuries to herd and protect sheep. The breed was used by the French Army as 
			sentries, messengers and to search for wounded soldiers because of its fine sense
			of hearin. Briards were used in the First World War almost to the point of extinction
			. Currently the population of briards is slowly recovering. Charlemagne, Napoleon
			, Thomas Jefferson and Lafayette all owned briards </p>
			<p id = "footer"> by Lvy Duckett </p>
		</body>
	</html> 
body 
{
	font-family: sans-sherif;
	color: gray;
}
#header
{
	text-shadow: -2px 3px 1px black;
	color: blue;
}
#subheader
{
	letter-spacing: 0.3em;
	text-transform: uppercase;
	color: lightblue;
}
p:first-line
{
	font-weight: bold;
	font-family: sherif;
}
a:link
{
	text-decoration: none;
	color: blue;
}
a:visited
{
	color:black;
}
[id $= "header2"]
{
	text-transform: capitalize;
	color: blue;
}

[id *= "oot"]
{
	text-align: right;
	font-style: italic;
}

SUMMARY CHAPTER TWELVE : TEXT

CHAPTER THIRTEEN : BOX

At the beginning of this section On CSS you saw how CSS treat every each HTML element as if it live inside it own box.

You can set several property that affect the appearence of this box. On this chapter you will look at :

  • Control the dimension of this box
  • Create Border around the box
  • Set padding and Margin for the box
  • Show And Hide the box

Once you learn how to control the appearence of this box you will see how to position this box on your page in Chapter 15 when you look at page layout.

Box Dimension

width , height

By default a box just big enough to hold its content. To set your own dimension for a box you can use the width and height property .

The most popular way to specify the size of the box are percentage , ems and pixel . Transitionally pixel are most commonly use because they allow designer to accurate control their size.

The use of percentage the size is relative to the size of the browser window or if it‚Äôs encased within another box . It‚Äôs percentage of the size of the containing box.

The use of ems the size is base on the text within the box. Recently Designer often use percentage and ems to create a design that flexible across device which have multiple size screen.

You can see the example below the size of the div box which use 300 pixel of wide by 300 pixel of height. And inside that box is a paragraph box that use 75% of width and height of the containing box. Which mean that the size of the paragraph box is a percentage of the size of the containing box which is div box 300 wide by 300 height. So the size of the paragraph is 225pixel of wide by 225pixel of height. 

<head>
	<link href = "example.css"
				rel  = "stylesheet"
				type = "text/css"/> </head>
	<body>
		<div>
			<p> The Moog company pioneered the commercial
			manufacture of modular voltage-controlled 
			analog synthesizer systems inthe early 1950s </p>
		</div>
	</body> 
		
body div 
{
	width: 300px;
	backgroud-color: red;
	height: 300px;
}
div+p
{
	width: 75%;
	height: 75%;
	background-color: blue;
}

Limiting Width

min-width , max-width

Some page design expand and shrink to fit the size of the user screen. For such Design min-width property specify the smaller size of the box can be display when the browser window is narrow. max-width indicate the maximum of the size of the box can stretch when the browser window is wide.

These are very helpful property to ensure the content on your page is legible ( Especially on the smaller screen of handheld device ). For example you can set the min-width property to make sure that the line of text are not appear narrow when the browser window is small. and the max-width property is to ensure that the text do not appear wide when the browser window is big.

You may find it helpful to try this example on your browser to see what happen when the size of the browser window is increase and decrease.

It is important to note that the these property were first support In Internet Explorer7 and fire fox using it on older version of these browser might not work.

<head>
	<link href = "example.css"
				rel  = "stylesheet"
				type = "text/css"/>
</head>
<body>
	<table>
		<td><img src = "example.jpeg" alt = "Jcole" width = "100" height = "100"></td>
		<td id = "description"> The Rhodes piano is an electro-mechanical piano, invented
		 by Harold Rhodes during fifities and later manufactured in a number of models, 
		 first in collaboration with Fender and after 1965 by CBS. It employs a piano-like
		 keyboard with hammers that hit small metaltines, amplified by electromagnetic 
		 pickeups . </td>
		<td> $1400 </td>
	</table>
</body>
td#description
{
	min-width: 100px;
	max-width: 300px;
	text-align: left;
}

Limited Height

min-height , max-height

In the same way you want to limited the width .You might also want to limit the height. To achieve this you can use the min-height and max-height property.

This example Show these property in action and also show you what happen when the content within the box take more space than the size specific for box .

If the box is not big enough to hold its content or the content expand outside the box . This can look messy. To control when there is not enough space for the content of the box you can use the overflow property which introduce next page.

<head> 
	<link href = "example.css"
				rel  = "stylesheet"
				type = "text/css">
</head>
<body>
	<h2>  Fender Mustang </h2>
	<p> The Fender Mustang was introduced in 1964 as the 
	basis of a major redesign of Fender's
 ... </p>	
	 <h2> Fender Stratocaster </h2>
	 <p> THe Fender Stratocaster or "Strat" is one of the most popular electric guitar
	 of all time ... </p>
	 <h2> Gibson Les Paul </h2>
	 <p> The Gibson Les Paul is a solid body electric guitar 
	 that was first sold in 1952 ... </p>
	</body>
h2 , p 
{
	width: 400px;
	font-size: 90%;
	line-height: 1.2em;
}
p
{
	min-height: 10px;
	max-height: 30px;
}

Overflowing Content

overflow

The overflow property will tell the browser what to do when the content within the box it larger than the box itself. It can take one of this value :

hidden

This simply hide the extra content that do not fit in the box.

scroll

Add a little scroll bar to the box so that users can use that scroll bar to see the missing content.

Below you can see two box and content on each box are expend beyond the set of their dimension. but the first are using the overflow property whose value is hidden and the last box also using the overflow property whose value is scroll ( which add scroll bar to the box that users can use to see missing content ) .

The overflow property is particularly handy . Because some browser do allow users to adjust the size of the text to appear as larger or as smaller as they want. If the text is set to larger which it will be unreadable mass. Hiding the overflow on such box help preventing items from overlapping on the the page. ( The statement mean that browser allow user to adjust the size base on the the users it could be larger or smaller but if the users put it larger it will be overlapping over element box or expand across which effect other box. That the reason that overflow come in to hide a items preventing it from overlapping on the page. ) 

<head> 
	<link href = "example.css"
				rel  = "stylesheet"
				type = "text/css">
</head>
<body>
	<h2>  Fender Mustang </h2>
	<p id = "mustang"> The Fender Mustang was introduced in 1964 as the 
	basis of a major redesign of Fender's
 ... </p>	
	 <h2 id = "stratocaster"> Fender Stratocaster </h2>
	 <p> THe Fender Stratocaster or "Strat" is one of the most popular electric guitar
	 of all time ... </p>
	 <h2> Gibson Les Paul </h2>
	 <p> The Gibson Les Paul is a solid body electric guitar 
	 that was first sold in 1952 ... </p>
	</body>
#mustang
{ 
	property: hidden;
}
#stratocaster
{ 
	property: scroll;
}

Border, Margin And Padding

Every box has three available property that allow you to adjust to control its appearence.

Border

Every box has a border ( even if it‚Äôs not visible or it have specific to be 0 pixel wide ) The border separate the edge of one box from another.

Margin

Margin sit outside the edge of the border. You can set the Margin of the box to separate the gap between border of two adjacent box.

Padding

Padding is the space between the border and the content contain within the box. Adding the padding increase the readability of its content .

If you specify the width of the box then the margin , padding and border are add to its width and height .

White Space And Vertical Margin

The padding and margin property are very helpful in adding space between various item on the page.

Designer often refer the space between item on the page as white space. Imagine that you have a border around the box and you might not want the text on the box or it would become harder to read. Or you might had a two box that sit side by side ( each have a black border ) you might not necessarily want the boxes to touch edge or it would make the edge line of that box will look twice as thick on the facing side.

If the bottom margin of any box touch the top margin of another. Browser tent to render it differently from what you might expected. it only show the larger of the two margin. If the margin is at the same size it only show one .

Border Width

border-width

The border-width property allow you to control the border of the width. The value of this property can be given as pixels and can take this following value :

  • thin
  • medium
  • thick

( You cannot use percentage for the value of this property )

You can control each individual width of the border using 4 separate property which is :

  • border-top-width
  • border-right-width
  • border-bottom-width
  • border-left-width

You can also specify the width for four border mention above in one property like this :

border-width: 1px , 2px, 3px , 3px;

These value appear in clockwise border-top-width , border-right-width , border-bottom-width and border-left-width.

<html>
	<head> 
		<link href = "example.css"
					rel  = "stylesheet"
					type = "text/css"/> </head>
		<body>
			<p class = "one"> Hohne's "Clavinet" is essentially an electric clavichord. </p>
			<p class = "two"> Hohne's "Clavinet" is essentially and electric clavichord. </p>
			<p class = "three"> Hohne's "Clavinet" is essentially and electric clavichord. </p>
		</body>
	</html>
.one 
{
	border-width: thin;
}
.two
{
	border-top-width: 1px;
	border-right-width: thin;
	border-bottom-width: 2px;
	border-left-width: thick;
}
.three 
{
	border-width: 1px , thin , 2px , thick;
}

Border Style

border-style

To control the style of the border you can use the border style property. The value of this property can take this following value :

  • solid : a single solid line .
  • dotted : a series of square dot if the users set the border 2px wide the dot is 2px square with the 2px gap between each other dot.
  • dash : a series of short line.
  • double : two solid line ( the value of the border-width property create the sum of two line ) .
  • groove : appear to be craved craved in to the page.
  • ridge : appear to stick out from the page.
  • inset : appear embedded in to the page.
  • outset : look like it coming out of the screen.
  • hidden / none : show no border

You also can control the style of each individual border using this 4 separate property :

  1. border-top-style
  1. border-right-style
  1. border-bottom-style
  1. border-left-style
<html>
<head>
	<link  href = "example.css"
				 rel = "stylesheet"
				type = "text/css"/>
</head>
<body>
			<p class = "one"> Hohne's "Clavinet" is essentially an electric clavichord. </p>
			<p class = "two"> Hohne's "Clavinet" is essentially and electric clavichord. </p>
			<p class = "three"> Hohne's "Clavinet" is essentially and electric clavichord. </p>
			<p class = "four"> Hohne's "Clavinet" is essentially an electric clavichord. </p>
			<p class = "five"> Hohne's "Clavinet" is essentially and electric clavichord. </p>
			<p class = "six"> Hohne's "Clavinet" is essentially and electric clavichord. </p>
			<p class = "seven"> Hohne's "Clavinet" is essentially an electric clavichord. </p>
			<p class = "eight"> Hohne's "Clavinet" is essentially and electric clavichord. </p>
			<p class = "nine"> Hohne's "Clavinet" is essentially and electric clavichord. </p>
			<p class = "ten"> Hohne's "Clavinet" is essentially and electric clavichord. </p>
</body>
</html>
.one{border-style: solid;}
.two{border-style: dotted;}
.three{border-style: double;}
.four{border-style: dashed;}
.five{border-style: groove;}
.six{border-style: ridge;}
.seven{border-style: inset;}
.eight{border-style: outset;}
.nine{border-style: none;}
.ten
{
	border-top-style: dashed;
	border-right-style: outset;
	border-bottom-style: double;
	border-left-style: groove;
}

Border-Color

border-color

The border-color property allow you to specify the color of the border using the rgb value , hex code and color name. It‚Äôs possible to use the HSL value to specify the border-color property however it was first introduce in CSS3 which not support in older code .

It‚Äôs possible for you to individual control the color for each of the side of the border using :

  • border-top-color:
  • border-right-color:
  • border-bottom-color:
  • border-left-color:

You could also use the shorthand way to specific the color for that four side of the border in one property like this

border-color: blue , red , green , yellow.

The value here appear in clockwise border-top-color , border-right-color, border-bottom-color , border-left-color .

<html>
	<head>
		<link href = "example.css"
					rel  = "stylesheet"
					type = "text/css"></head>
	<body>
		<p class = "one"> The ARP Odyssey was introduced in 1972 </p>
		<p class = "two"> The ARP Odyssey was introduces in 1972 </p>
		<p class = "three"> The ARP odyssey was introduces in 1972 </p> 
	</body>
	</html>
.one 
	{
		border-width: 10px;
		border-style: solid;
		border-color: rgb(255 , 0 , 0 );
	}
.two
{
	border-width: 10px;
	border-style: double;
	border-top-color: red;
	border-right-color: blue;
	border-bottom-color: green;
	border-left-color: black;
}
.three
{
	border-color: red , blue , green , cyan;
	border-width: 20px;
	border-style: dashed;
}

Shorthand

border

The border property allow you to specify the width , style and color of the border in one property. ( ensure that the value is in a specific order , width , style , color) .

border: 10px , solid , red;

<html>
	<head>
		<link href = "example.css"
					 rel = "stylesheet"
					type = "text/css"/>
		</head>
	<body>
		<p> Here is a simple chord sequence played on a Hammond organ
		through a Leslie speaker. </p>
	</body>
</html>
p {
	border: 10px , solid , red;
}

Padding

The padding property allow you to specify how much space should appear between the content of the its element and its border.

The value of this property most often specify in pixel although it can be use percentages and ems . If it use percentages It‚Äôs the percentage of the window browser or It‚Äôs percentage of the containing box if the box encased within another box.

Note that if the width is specify for the box. Padding is add on to the width of the box.

As you can see below the paragraph text is easier to read here because the space between the text and its border. The box can also become wider if it has padding.

You can specify individual each value for each side of the box using this 4 separate property :

  • padding-top
  • padding-right
  • padding-bottom
  • padding-left

You can use the shorthand to specify the value for each side of the box using this

padding: 10px 10px 10px 10px

The value appear here is in clockwise padding-top , padding-right , padding-bottom , padding-left.

And there is a shorthand that you might see something like this

padding: 10px 20px

it mean that left and right padding should be 10px and top and bottom padding should be 20px.

The value of these padding property do not inherit from the child element in the same way of that color value of the font-family property. So you need to specify the padding element for every element that need to use it.

Up until the internet Explorer 6. The width of the box would need to include the padding and the margins. 

<html>
	<head>
		<link href = "example.css"
					rel  = "stylesheet"
					type = "text/css"/>
	</head>
	<body>
		<p class = "one"> Analog synths produce a wave sound whereas the sounds
											stored on a digital synth have been sampled and then
											turned into numbers. </p>
	</body>
</html> 
.one 
{
	padding: 10px;
}
.one 
{
	padding-top: 10px;
	padding-right: 10px;
	padding-bottom: 10px;
	padding-left: 10px;
}
.one 
{
	padding: 10px 10px 10px 10px
}
.one 
{
	padding: 10px 10px
}

Margin

margin

The margin property allow you to control the gap between box. The value of these property often specific in pixel although it could use percentage and ems.

If one box sit on another box margin are collapse. it mean that the larger margin will be use of the two margin. and the smaller one will be disregard. And if the it‚Äôs the same size the size of the same margin will be use of the two same size .

Note that if the width specific for the box. Margin can add on to the width of that box.

You can specify individual value for each of side of the box using this four separate property:

  • margin-top
  • margin-right
  • margin-bottom
  • margin-left

You can also use the shorthand version to specify the value for the side of the border using this

margin: 10px 10px 20px 20px

which this value appear in clockwise meaning that it appear margin-top margin-right margin-bottom margin-left.

Sometime you might see something like this

margin: 10px 20px

which mean the left and right margin should be 10px and the top and bottom should be 20px.

The value of the margin property do not inherit by the child element in the same way that color value of the font-family. So you would need to specify margin on every element that need to use it.

Up until Internet Explorer 6 the width of the box would need to include padding and margin. 

<html>
	<head>
		<link href = "example.css"
					rel  = "stylesheet"
					type = "text/css"/>
		</head>
	<body>
		<p class =  "one"> Analog synths produce a wave sound, whereas the sound stored on 
		a digital synth have been sampled and then turned into numbers. </p>
	</body>
</html>
.one 
{
	margin: 10px;
}
.one
{
	margin-top: 10px;
	margin-right: 10px;
	margin-bottom: 10px;
	margin-left: 10px;
}
.one
{
	margin: 10px 10px 10px 10px;
}
.one
{
 margin: 10px 20px;
}

Centering Content

If you wan to center the box on the page or center within the element that the box sit inside you can sit margin left and margin right to auto.

In order to center the box on the page or within the element that the box sit inside you need to specify the width for the box otherwise it will take up the full width of the page.

Once you have specify the width for the box setting the left margin and right margin to auto will make browser put equal gaps on each side of the box . This make the box center on the page or it center within the element that box sit inside.

In order for it to work in older browser particularly IE6 the element that the box sit inside that element need to have a text-align property whose value is center.

The text align property is inherit from the child element meaning that the box that sit inside that element will be inherit that element so therefore you need to specify the text align property on the center box that you don‚Äôt want the text in that box to be align center.

<html>
	<head>
		<link href = "example.css"
					rel  = "stylesheet"
					type = "text/css"/>
	</head>
	<body>
		<p class = "one"> Analog synthesizers are often said to have a "warmer" sound
											than their digital counterparts. </p>
	</body>
	</html>			
p 
{
	width: 500px;
	border:10px inset blue;
	padding: 20px;
	margin: 20px auto 20px auto;
}

Internet Explorer Box Model

When you specify the width for the box the padding and margin are add on to the width of the box. Internet Explorer6 However have a quirk whereas it include the padding and margin in the page.

The way around this to ensure you provide a DOCTYPE declaration for the HTML page. You can use either HTML5 HTML4 HTML4 Strict HTML4 Transition and DOCTYPE HTML declaration. To make sure the Internet Explorer6 follow the correct box model.

Here you see the demonstrate on the example below shown in Internet Explorer. The first example provide a DOCTYPE declaration and another one do not provide a DOCTYPE declaration.

Change Inline / Block

display

The display property allow you to turn a inline element into a block element or block element into a inline element . And it can also use to hide an element from the page.

This property can take this following value :

inline

This cause the block element act like a inline element.

block

This cause the inline element act like a block element.

inline-block

This cause the block element flow like a inline element while retaining other features of the block element.

none

This hide an element. But in this case although the element is not on the page . Users can still see the content of the hide box by viewing the source option in their browser.

If you use this property it‚Äôs important to note that the inline box are not suppose to create a block element.

In this example below you can see the <li> element and each item inside the <li> are usually treat as a block element. But in this case the <li> indicate the rule should be treat as a inline element. meaning that the item that sit inside the <li> element will be sit along side of each other rather than appearing on the new line.

This technique is often use to create a navigation for the site. In this example margin were add to the right for each of items so separate them out. And the <li> element that have a class attribute and that class attribute have a value coming soon have been hidden as if it was not on the page.

<html>
	<head>
		<link href = "example.css"
					rel  = "stylesheet"
					type = "text/css"/>
	</head>
	<body>
		<ul>
			<li> Home </li>
			<li> About </li>
			<li> Users </li>
			<li> search </li>
			<li class = "comming soon"> comming soon </li>
		</ul>
	</body>
</html> 
li
{
	display: inline;
	margin-right: 10px;
}
li.comming soon{
	display: none;
}

Hiding Boxes

visibility

The visibility property allow you to hide the box from the users. But it add space where the element has been hidden has been.

This property can take this two value :

hidden

This hide the elements.

visible

This show the elements.

If the visibility of the element is set to hidden mean that the element is hide from the users but it put blank space where the element is hidden in that place.

If you do not want a black space is place in the element place that are hidden you should use the display with a value none instead ( talk above ) .

Please note that the content of the visibility that set to hidden still can be view by the users from the source option in their browser.

<html>
	<head>
		<link href = "example.css"
					rel  = "stylesheet"
					type = "text/css"/>
  </head>
  <body>
	  <ul>
		  <li> Home </li>
		  <li> Users </li>
		  <li class = "comming soon"> Comming soon </li>
		  <li> search </li>
		  <li> About </li>
		</ul>
	</body>
</html>
li
{
	margin-right: 10px;
	display: inline;
	visibility: visible;
	
}
li.comming soon
{
	margin-right: inherit;
	visibility: hidden;
}

CSS3: Border Images

border-image

The border images property allow you to applied image to the border of any box. It take the background images and slices it into nine pieces .

Here the images that the author have add mark where it‚Äôs been slices. In this example taking 18pixel from each of the corner to place an entire box from each of corner. The corner slices are always place in four corner of the box. But we have choice weather the side of box is stretch or repeat.

This property must contain these three piece o information.

  1. The URL of the images
  1. Where to slice the images
  1. What to do with the straight edge it can take this possible value.
    • stretch : stretch the images.
    • repeat : repeat the images.
    • round : repeat the images but if the tile is not fit exactly scale the tile images so they will

The box must have a border width in order the images to be shown .

The -moz-border-images and -webkit-border-images are not specification in CSS but help earlier version of Chrome Firefox and Safari display this effect.

<head>
	<link href = "example.css"
				type = "text/css"
				rel  = "stylesheet"/>
</head>
<body>
	<p class = "one"> </p>
	<p class = "two"> </p>
	<p class = "three"> </p>
</body>
.one
{
	-moz-border-image: url("images/dot.gif") 11 11 11 11 stretch;
	-webkit-border-image: url("images/dot.gif") 11 11 11 11 stretch;
	border-image: url("images/dot.gif") 11 11 11 11 stretch;
}
.two
{
	-moz-border-image: url("images/dot.gif") 11 11 11 11 round;
	-webkit-border-image: url("images/dot.gif") 11 11 11 11 round;
  border-image: url("images/dot.gif") 11 11 11 11 round;
}

CSS3: Box Shadow

box-shadow

The box-shadow property allow you to add the drop shadow to any box just like you a shadow-text property that you met. This box-shadow property can take these two value and the color value.

Horizontal Offset

Negative value position the shadow of the box to the left. And positive value position shadow of the box to the right.

Vertical Offset

Negative value position the shadow of the box to the top. And positive value position shadow of the box to the bottom.

Blur Distance

If this value is omitted. The shadow is a solid line like a border.

Spread Of Shadow

If this uses . Positive value will make the shadow expand in all direction. While negative value will make it contrast.

The inset keyword can be use before these value to create a inner shadow.

Chrome , Firefox and Safari are quick to support these property using -moz-border-shadow and -webkit-border-shadow property. But these are not CSS specification but help to them to work in these browser.

<head>
	<link href = "images/css"
				type = "text/css"
				rel  = "stylesheet">
</head>
<body>
	<p class = "one"></p>
	<p class = "two"></p>
	<p class = "three"></p>
	<p class = "four"></p>
</body>

.one
{
	-moz-box-shadow: -5px -5px #777777;
	-webkit-box-shadow: -5px -5px #777777;
	box-shadow: -5px -5px #777777;
}
.two
{
	-moz-box-shadow: 5px 5px 5px #777777;
	-webkit-box-shadow: 5px 5px 5px #777777;
	box-shadow: 5px 5px 5px #777777;
}
.three 
{
	-moz-box-shadow: 5px 5px 5px 5px #777777;
	-webkit-box-shadow: 5px 5px 5px 5px #777777;
	box-shadow: 5px 5px 5px 5px #777777;
}
.four
{
	-moz-box-shadow: 0px 0px 10px #777777;
	-webkit-box-shadow: 0px 0px 10px #777777;
	box-shadow: 0px 0px 10px #777777;
}
.five
{
	-moz-box-shadow: inset 0px 0px 10px #777777;
	-webkit-box-shadow: inset 0px 0px 10px #77777;
	box-shadow: inset 0px 0px 10px #77777;
}

CSS3: Rounded Corners

border-radius

CSS3 introduces a ability that let users to create a round border using this property called border-radius. The value of this property is the size of the radius in pixels .

Older browser that do not support this property just show the box with the right angled corner.

The -moz-border-radius and the -webkit-border-radius property are not the CSS specification. However they are use in several version of Browser , Firefox , Chrome and Safari to offer early support this style and therefore can be use to achieve this effect in more browser.

You can specify value for individual side of the corner using this 4 separate property:

border-top-right-radius

border-top-left-radius

border-bottom-right-radius

border-bottom-left-radius

You can use the shorthand way which specify These individual side of the corner in one property. The value in here appear in clockwise order border-top-left-radius border-top-right-radius border-bottom-right-radius border-bottom-left-radius.

border-radius: 10px 10px 20px 20px

<head>
	<link href = "example.css"
				rel  = "stylsheet"
				type = "text/css">
</head>
<body>
	<p class = "one"> Pets Sounds Ffeatured a number of 
	uncoventional instruments such as bicycle bells, flutes,
	Electro-Theremin, dog whistles, trains, Hawaii-sounding string
	instruments, Coca-Cola cans cand barking dogs. </p>
</body> 
p
{
	border: 10px solid red;
	margin: 20px;
	padding: 20px
	border-radius: 10px;
}

CSS3: Elliptical Shapes

border-radius

To create more complex shape you need to specify different distance for the horizontal-part and the vertical part of the round corner.

For example you can create a wider than its tall. For example border-radius: 80px 50px;

You can target only one corner using the individual property like this :

border-top-left-radius: 80px 50px; ( this target only the border-top-left ).

You can targeting all four corner at once. First you need to specify the four value for the horizontal part and than you need to specify the four value for the vertical part. Shown below:

border-radius: 10px 10px 10px 10px / 20px 20px 20px 20px

this value appear of horizontal and vertical appear in clockwise top-left, top-right , bottom-right, bottom-left.

You can even create a circle by taking a square box and making the border radius the same height as the square box. Just like this

border-radius: 100px;

<head>
	<link href = "example.css"
				rel  = "stylesheet"
				type = "text/css"/>
</head>
<body>
<p class = "one"> </p>
<p class = "two"> </p>
<p class = "three"> </p>
<p class = "four"> </p>
</body>
.one 
{
	border: 10px solid red;
	margin: 10px;
	padding: 10px;
	border-radius: 80px 50px;
}
.two
{
	border: 10px solid red;
	margin: 10px;
	padding: 10px;
	border-top-left-radius: 80px 50px;
	border-top-right-radius: 80px 50px;
	border-bottom-right-radius: 80px 50px;
	border-bottom-left-radius: 80px 50px;
}
.three
{
	border: 10px solid red;
	margin: 10px;
	padding: 10px;
	border-radius: 10px 11px 12px 13px / 9px 8px 7px 6px;
}
.four
{
	border: 10px solid red;
	margin: 10px;
	padding: 10px;
	border-radius: 100px;
}

Example Boxes

In this example, you can see a simple homepage for a music shop.

The whole page sits inside a <div> element and an id of page. This is centered using the margin property with a value auto for the left and right margin. The logo and other contents are centered using the same technique.

The navigation is create using an unordered list. There are borders set to the top and bottoms of this list to make it stand out. The display property has been applied to each of the items in this list so they behave like inline ( rather than block element ) elements. This enables the navigation links to sit next to each other horizontally. The padding property has been used to create space between each of the links.

The width property for the <ul> element is set to 570 pixels. and the width property for the <p> elements beneath them is set to 600pixels. They actually end the same width as each other because the <ul> element also uses padding to creating gap between the border of the box it create and the link inside of it. and any padding , border, or margins are added to the width and height of the box.

if we had not included a DOCTYPE declaration at the start of the page the sizes of the boxes would be different to each other in IE6 because this browser did not implement the box model in the correct way.

<!DOCTYPE html PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD XHTML 1.0 Strict//EN"
"https://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-strict.dtd">
<html>
    <head>
        <title> Example Boxes </title>
        <link href = "CHAPTER13.X.css"
              rel  = "stylesheet"
              type = "text/css"/>
    </head>
    <body>
        <div id = "page">
            <div id = "logo">
                <img src    = "images/https___images.genius.com_ae722fa8fa10d75fe4b25dfeb4b8d8d6.1000x1000x1.jpg"
                     alt    = "logo"
                     title  = "J Cole"
                     width  = "200"
                     height = "200"/>
            </div>
            <ul id = "navigation">
                <li><a href = "#"> Home </a></li>
                <li><a href = "#"> For Sale </a></li>
                <li><a href = "#"> Repairs </a></li>
                <li><a href = "#"> About </a></li>
                <li><a href = "#"> Contact </a></li>
            </ul>
            <p id = "picture">
                <img src = "images/681723-berserk-hd-wallpaper-background.jpg"
                     alt = "berserk"
                     title = "berserk"
                     width = "500"
                     height = "200"/>
            </p>
            <p id = "paragraph"> We specialize in the sale and repair of classic keyboards, in 
                particular the Fender Rhodes, Wurlitzer EP200, and Hohner Clavinet.    
            </p>
        </div>
    </body>
</html>
body 
{
    font-family: monospace;
    line-height: 1.43em;
    letter-spacing: 0.1em;
}
#page
{
    border-width:10px;
    border-style: double;
    width: 750px;
    height: 800px;
    margin-top: 10px;
    margin-bottom: 10px;
    margin-right: auto;
    margin-left: auto;
    min-width: 450px;
    max-width: 600px;
    min-height: 300px;
    max-height: 700px;
    padding: 20px;
}
#logo
{
   margin-left: auto;
   margin-right: auto;
   width: 400px;
   margin-top: 10px;
   margin-bottom: 10px;
   padding: 10px;
   text-align: center;
}
a:link
{
    text-decoration: none;
    color: black;
    text-transform: uppercase;
}
a:hover
{
    color:orange;
}
li 
{
    display: inline;
    padding: 10px;
    margin-right: auto;
    margin-left: auto;
    margin-top: 15px;
    margin-left: 15px;
}
ul 
{
    text-align: center;
    padding: 10px;
    margin: 10px auto 10px auto;
    border-top-color: black;
    border-top-style: solid;
    border-top-width: thick;
    border-bottom-style: solid;
    border-bottom-color: black;
    border-bottom-width: thin;
}
#picture 
{
    margin-top: 10px;
    padding: 10px;
    margin-bottom: 10px;
    margin-left: auto;
    margin-right: auto;
    width: 400px;
}
#paragraph
{
    text-align: center;
    margin: 40px auto 10px auto;
    padding: 10px;
    width: 400px

}

SUMMARY CHAPTER THIRTEEN : BOXES

CHAPTER FOURTEEN : Lists , Tables And Forms

There are several CSS property that were create to work with specific type of HTML elements such as lists , table and form.

In this chapter you will learn how to :

  • Specify the type for the bullet point or numbering list.
  • Add border and background to the table cells.
  • Control the appearence of the form control.

Together this property allow you to take finer control over specific part of the page.

Bullets Point Styles

list-style-type

The list-style-type property allow you to control the shape or the style of the bullet point ( also known as marker ) .

It can be use on the rule that applied to the <ol> , <ul> , <li> elements.

unorder lists

For unorder lists this list-style-type can take this following value:

none

disc

square

circle

Order lists

For Order lists or numbering lists this list-style-type can take this following value:

decimal

decimal-leading-zero

lower-alpha

upper-alpha

lower-roman

upper-roman

<head>
	<link href = "example.css"
				type = "text/css"
				rel  = "stylesheet"/>
</head>
<body>
	<h1> The Complete Poems </h1>
	<h2> Emily Dickinson </h2>
	<ol>
		<li> Life </li>
		<li> Nature </li>
		<li> Love </li>
		<li> Time and Eternity </li>
		<li> The Single Hound </li>
	</ol>
</body>
ol
{
	list-style-type: lower-roman;
}
li
{
	margin-top: 20px;
}

Images For Bullets

list-style-image

You can specify the images and let it act as a bullet points using the property called list-style-image.

The value of this list-style-image property start with letter url follow by the pair of parenthesis and inside the parenthesis you specify the path to the images inside the double quote.

This property can be use on the rule that applied to <ul> and <li> elements also <ol> elements.

This example show the use of the margin to increase the vertical gap between each items .

<head>
	<link href = "example.css"
				rel  = "stylesheet"
				type = "text/css"/>
</head>
<body>
	<h1> Index of Translated Poems </h1>
	<h2> Arthur Rimbaud </h2>
	<ul>
		<li> Ophelia </li>
		<li> To Music </li>
		<li> A Dream of Winter </li>
		<li> Vowels </li>
		<li> The Drunken Boat </li>
	</ul>
</head>
ul
{
	list-style-image: url("images.jpeg");
}
li
{
	margin-top: 10px;
}

Positioning The Marker

list-style-position

lists are indents into the page by default. list-style-position allow you to indicate whether the marker should appear inside or outside of the box containing the main point.

This property can take this one of these two value:

outside

The marker sit to the left of the block of text ( this is a default behaviour if this property is not use ).

inside

The marker sit inside within the box of text ( which is indent )

In this example have shown the width has been limit to 150px to ensure that the text wrap on the new line so you can see how the value of inside sit the bullets inside the first line of text.

A margin has been add to each item to make gap between each. 

<head>
	<link href = "example.css"
				rel  = "stylesheet"
				type = "text/css"/>
</head>
<body>
	<ul class = "outside">
		<li> That idol, black eyes and yellow mop, without parents or court ... </li>
		<li> Gracious son of Pan! Around your forehead crowned with flowerets ... </li>
		<li> When the world is reduced to a single dark wood for our four ... </li>
	</ul>
	<ul class = "inside">
		<li> Once, if my memory serves me well, my life was a banquet ... </li>
		<li> Hadn't I once a youth that was lovely, heroic, fabulous ... </li>
		<li> Autumn already! - But why regret the everlasting sun if we are ... </li>
	</ul>
</body>
li
{
	margin: 10px
	width: 150px;
}
ul.outside
{
	list-style-position: outside;
}
ul.inside
{
	list-style-postion: inside;
}

List Shorthand

list-style

Just like several other CSS property. This is a shorthand property that act like a shorthand which allow you to express mark a style , image and position in any order in one property.

<head>
	<link href = "example.css"
				rel  = "stylesheet"
				type = "text/css">
</head>
<body>
	<h1> Quotes from Edgar Allan Poe </h1>
		<ul>
			 <li> I have great faith in foots; self-confidence my friends call it. </li>
			 <li> All that we see or seem is but a dream within a dream. </li>
			 <li> I wouldn't define, in brief, the poetry of words as the 
			 rhythmical creation of Beauty . </li>
		</ul>
ul
{
	list-style: inside circle;
	width: 300px;
}
li{
	margin: 10px;
}

Table Properties

You have already met several CSS property that are commonly use in table. Here we put them together in the example using this following :

width

Set the width of the tables.

padding

Set space between the border of each table cell and its content.

text-transform

To convert the content of the table heading into uppercase.

letter-spacing , font-size

To add addition style to the content of the heading.

border-top , border-bottom

To set border above or bottom the table header.

text-align

Align the writing to the left of some table cell and to the right of other.

background-color

You can change background color of the alternating table row.

:hover

Highlight the table rows when user mouse move over it.

Here are some tips for styling table to ensure that they are clean and easy to follow :

Give Cells Padding

If the text inside the border cell touch the border or any other table cells. It will become harder to read add padding can help improve readability.

Distinguish Heading

putting the heading in bold which is the <th> default behaviour make it easier to read. You can put the heading in uppercase or adding either a background color or underline to clearly distinguish them from the content.

Shade Alternate Rows

Shading every other row can help the users follow along the line. Use of subtle distinction from the normal color of the rows to keep the table looking clean.

Align Numerals

You can use the align property on any column that contain a number to the right. So that the larger number clearly distinguish from the smaller one.

<!DOCTYPE html PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD XHTML 1.0 Strict//EN"
"https://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-strict.dtd">
<html>
    <head>
        <title> Table Property </title>
        <link href = "CHAPTER14.4.CSS"
              rel  = "stylesheet"
              type = "text/css"/>
    </head>
    <body>
        <h1> First Edition Auctions </h1>
        <table> 
            <tr class = "author">
                <th> Author </th>
                <th> Title  </th>
                <th class = "left"> Reserve Price </th>
                <th class = "left"> Current Bid </th>
            </tr>
            <tr class = "user1">
                <td> E.E Cummings </td>
                <td> Tulips & Chimneys </td>
                <td class = "left"> $2,000.000 </td>
                <td class = "left"> $2,642.50  </td>
            </tr>
            <tr class = "user2">
                <td> Charles d'Orleans </td>
                <td> Poemes </td>
                <td class = "left">  </td>
                <td class = "left"> $5,866.00 </td>
            </tr>
            <tr class = "user3">
                <td> T.S.Eliot </td>
                <td> Poems 1909 - 1925 </td>
                <td class = "left"> $1,250.00 </td>
                <td class = "left"> $8,499.35 </td>
            </tr>
            <tr class = "user4">
                <td> Sylvia Plath </td>
                <td> The Colossus </td>
                <td class = "left">  </td>
                <td class = "left"> $1031.72 </td>
            </tr>
        </table>
    </body>
</html>
		
body 
{
    font-family: monospace;
    font-size: 16px;
}
h1 
{
    font-family: "Press Start 2P";
}

th
{
    padding: 10px;
    text-transform: uppercase;
    border-top-width: thin;
    border-top-style: solid;
    border-top-color: black;
    border-bottom-width: medium;
    border-bottom-style: solid;
    letter-spacing: 0.1em;
    font-size: 100%;
    text-align: left;
    font-style: bold;
}
.left
{
    text-align: right;
}
.user2  , .user4  
{
    background-color: antiquewhite;
}
tr:hover
{
    background-color: rgb(24, 171, 122);
}
.user1 td , .user2 td , .user3 td , .user4 td  
{
    width: 600px;
    padding: 10px;
}

Border On Empty Cells

empty-cells

If you have a empty cells in your table. The use of empty property to specify whether or not the border will shown.

Browser treat empty cells in many different way. If you want to explicit hide or show the border in any empty cell you should use this empty-cells property.

This empty-cells can take this following value:

hide

This hide the border of any empty cells.

show

This show the border of any empty cells.

inherit

If the table is in nested of another table. The inherit value instruct that the table cells should obey the rule of the containing table.

The example below show the first table with the border are show in the empty cells and the second table show the table without a border in the empty cells. Meaning that the first one use the empty-cells with the value show and the second one use the empty-cells with the value hide.

<head>
	<link href = "example.css"
				rel  = "stylesheet"
				type = "text/css"/>
</head>
<body>
	<table class = "one">
			<tr>
				<td> 1 </td>
				<td> 2 </td>
			</tr>
			<tr>
				<td> 3 </td>
				<td> </td>
			</tr>
			</table>
		  <table class = "two">
			  <tr>
		    <td> 1 </td>
		    <td> 2 </td>
		   </tr>
		   <tr>
			   <td> 3 </td>
			   <td> </td>
			  </tr>
			 </table>
	</body> 
td
{
	border-weight: 10px;
	border-style: solid;
	border-color: red;
	padding: 25px;
}
table.one{
empty-cells: show;
}
table.two{
empty-cells: hide;
}

Gaps Between Cells

border-spacing , border-collapse

The border-spacing allow you to control the distance between the adjacent cells. By Default browser do add a small gaps between table cells. This border-spacing allow you to increase or decrease the space and allow you to control the gaps.

The value of this property often specify in pixel. And often take two value if desired two separate number for horizontal part and vertical parts.

When border are use in the table cells. Where two cells met the width of line will be twice that of the outside edge. It‚Äôs possible to collapse the border to prevent this using the property call border-collapse. This border-collapse property can take this following value:

collapse

Border are collapse into a single border where possible ( border-spacing are ignored , cell are put together and the empty cell are ignored ) .

separate

Border are detected from each other ( border-spacing and empty cell will be obey ) .

<head>
	<link href = "example.css"
				rel  = "sheetstyle"
			 type  = "text/css"/>
</head>
<body>
	<table class = "one">
		<tr>
			<td> 1 </td>
			<td> 2 </td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td> 3 </td>
			<td>   </td>
		</tr>
		</table>
		<table class = "two">
			<tr>
				<td> 1 <td/>
				<td> 2 </td>
			</tr>
			<tr>
				<td> 3 </td>
				<td>   </td>
			</tr>
		</table>
	</body>	
th
{
	padding: 10px;
	border-style: solid;
	border-weight: 10px;
	border-color: red;
}
.one
{
	border-spacing: 10px 20px;
	empty-cells: show;
}
.two
{
	border-colapse: collapse;
}

Styling Forms

Nobody I know enjoy filling the forms. So if you can make your form look more attractive and easier to use more people are likely to fill in your form. So When you come back and look at your form in a few different browser. You can see that each browser display your form differently.

CSS is commonly use to control the appearence of the Form element. This is both use to make your form look more attractive and to make them look more consistent across different browser.

It‚Äôs most commonly use to style :

  • The text input and text areas
  • Submit Buttons
  • Label on form to get the form control align nicely.

Styling the text input and submit buttons is fairly easy. But it‚Äôs harder to get the checkbox , radio box and select box to look more consistent across different browser. To achieve this you might like to download the CSS file at https://formalize.me. The author of this website has done a work hard to make the form look consistent across different browser. Although the solution incorporate with JavaScript no prior knowledge is need here in order to implement .

Styling Text Inputs

This example demonstrates the CSS property commonly used with text inputs, most of which you have already met.

font-size

sets the size of the text entered by the users.

color

sets the text color.

background-color

sets the background color of the inputs.

border

adds a border around the edge of the input box.

border-radius

Can be use to create rounded corners ( for browser that support this property ) .

:focus

pseudo-class is used to change background color of the text input when it being used meaning that if that element have been focus all the property will be applied to that element unless user click on other element so that the focus property of that element ( that click ) will applied to that element

:hover

pseudo-class applied the same styles when users hovers over them.

background-image

adds a background images to the box. Because there is a different image for each input, we are using an attribute selector looking for the value of the id attribute on each input.

<!DOCTYPE html PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD XHTML 1.0 Strict//EN"
"https://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-strict.dtd">
<html>
    <head>
        <title> Style Input Type </title>
        <link href = "CHAPTER14.7.css"
              rel  = "stylesheet"
              type = "text/css"/>
    </head>
    <body>
        <input type = "text"
               name = "Email"
               required = "required"/>
        <br/>
    
        <input type = "text"
               name = "Web"
               required =  "required"/>
        
        <br/>

        <input type = "text"
               name = "internet"
               required = "required"/>
    </body>
</html>

input 
{
    width: 200px;
    height: 30px;
    margin-bottom: 10px;
    color:bisque;
    background-color: grey;
    font-family: monospace;
    font-size: 15px;
    border-radius: 10px 5px;
    border-width: thin;
    border-style: solid;
    padding: 5px
}
[type="text"]:focus , [type="text"]:hover 
{
    width: 500px;
    text-shadow: 4px 2px 5px red;
    font-size: 200%;
    font-family: "Press Start 2P";
    box-shadow: 4px 2px 5px 5px red;
}

Styling Submit Buttons

Here ae some properties that can be used to style submit buttons. This example build on the one previous page, and the submit button inherits the style set for the <input> element on the last page.

color

Is used to change the color of the text on the button.

text-shadow

Can give a 3D look to the text in browsers that support this property.

border-bottom

Has been used to make the bottom border of the button slightly thicker, which give it more 3D feel.

background-color

Can make the submit button stand out from other items around it. ( Creating a consistent style for all buttons help users understand how they should interact with the site . ) A gradient background has been added for browsers that support gradients.

:hover

The :hover pseudo-class has been used to change the appearence of the button when the users hover over it. In this case the background changes the text gets darker, and the thicker border is applied to the top of the border. h

<!DOCTYPE html PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD XHTML 1.0 Strict//EN"
"https://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-strict.dtd">
<html>
    <head>
        <title> Styling Submit Button </title>
        <link href = "CHAPTER14.8.css"
              rel  = "stylesheet"
              type = "text/css"/>
    </head>
    <body>
        <input type  = "submit"
               value = "Register"
               name  = "submit"/>
    </body>
</html>
[type = "submit"]
{
    height: 30px;
    width: 100px;  
    text-shadow: 1px 1px 2px red;
    border-radius: 5px;
    border-style: solid;
    border-color:gray;
    border-bottom-width: 3px;
    background-color: aquamarine;
}
[type = "submit"]:hover 
{
    height: 30px;
    width: 100px;
    text-shadow: 1px 1px 2px red;
    border-radius: 5px;
    border-top-style: solid;
    border-top-width: 3px;
    border-color: gray;
    background-color: rgb(255, 34, 0);
}

Styling Fieldset And Legends

Fieldset are particularly helpful in determining the edges of a form. In a long form they can help group together related information within it.

The legend is used to indicate what information is required in the fieldset.

Properties commonly used with these two elements include:

width

is used to control the width of the fieldset. In this example, the width of the fieldset forces the form elements to wrap onto a new line in the correct place. ( if it were wider the items might sit on one line ) .

color

is used to control the color of text.

background-color

is used to change the color behind these items.

border

is used to control the appearence of the border around the fieldset and/or legend.

border-radius

is used to soften the edges of these elements in browsers that support this property.

padding

can be used to add space inside these element.

<!DOCTYPE html PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD XHTML 1.0 Strict//EN"
"https://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-strict.dtd">
<html>
    <head> 
        <title> Styling Fieldsets and Legends </title>
        <link href = "CHAPTER14.9.css"
              rel  = "stylesheet"
              type = "text/css">
    </head>
    <body>
        <fieldset>
            <legend> newsletter </legend>
            <span> Name: </span> 
            <input type = "text"
                   name = "text"/>
            Email:
            <input type = "text"
                   name = "text"/>
            <input type = "submit"
                   value = "Subscribe">
            
        </fieldset>
    </body>
</html>
fieldset
{
    width: 250px;
    padding: 45px;
    border-width: 2px;
    border-radius: 15px;
    border-style: solid;
    border-color: gray;
    font-family: monospace;
}
legend 
{
    border: 2px solid gray;
    text-transform: uppercase;
    padding: 12px;
    border-radius: 10px;
    background-color: rgb(229, 216, 216);
    text-align: left;
}
[type="text"]
{
    margin: 10px;
    border-top-width: 0px;
    border-left-width: 0px;
    border-right-width: 0px;
}
span 
{
    margin-right: 7px;
}
[type="submit"]
{
    color: whitesmoke;
    border-radius: 5px;
    background-color:gray;
    margin-top: 30px;
    margin-left: 200px;
}
[type="submit"]:hover
{
    color: gray;
    border-radius: 5px;
    background-color:rgb(255, 255, 255);
    margin-top: 30px;
    margin-left: 200px;
}

Aligning Form Controls : Problem

Label for form element are often different length. Which mean that the form control will not appear on the straight line. This demonstrate on in the example below.

In this form each question that we ask users about is inside the <div> elements to ensure that each question is appear on the new line. It‚Äôs easier to let users to fill in the form if the form is align in a straight vertical line.

If you look at where we ask the users about their gender. The two radio button each have their own label ( one saying male and another one saying female ) and also the <span> element have been add to the title which help align these control.

On the previous page you can saw another technique to align the form element. When the form only contain a text input. Setting all the input text in the same width as well as aligning all the form control to the right. The fields are line up the label are in the consistent place. For more complex form you can need to use the solution shown in these page .

<!DOCTYPE html PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD XHTML 1.0 Strict//EN"
"https://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-strict.dtd">
<html>
    <head>
        <title>  Align Form Control Problem </title> 
    </head>
    <body>
        <form action = "login.php" method = "post">
            <div>
                <label for = "text"> Name: </label>
                <input type = "text"
                       id   = "text"> 
            </div>
            <div>
                <label for = "email"> Email: </label>
                <input type = "text"
                       id   = "email">
            </div>
            <div>
                <span> Gender: </span>
                <input type = "radio"
                       name = "gender"
                       value = "male"
                       id  = "male"> <label for = "male"> M </label>
                <input type = "radio"
                       name = "gender"
                       value = "Female"
                       id = "female"> <label for = "female"> F </label>
            </div>
            <div>
                <input type = "submit"
                       value = "Register"/>
            </div>
        </form>
    </body>
</html>

Aligning Form Controls : Solution

Each row of the form has a title which telling users what they need to enters. For input text title is in the <label> element and for the radio button that title is in the <span> elements. both have a class attribute with a value title.

We use the property called float to move the title to left or right The float property are cover on the next chapter.

By setting the width property on those element we know that the title will each take up the same width. And therefore the form control next to them will line up.

The text-align property allow you to align the title to the right. Use of padding ensure that the gap between the text in the title box and the form controls.

Style are applied to the <div> element that contain each row of the form ( fixing their width and creating vertical space between each rows ) The submit button is also align to the right.

<!DOCTYPE html PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD XHTML 1.0 Strict//EN"
"https://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-strict.dtd">
<html>
    <head>
        <title> Aligning Form Controls: Solution </title>
        <link href = "CHAPTER14.11.css"
               rel = "stylesheet"
              type = "text/css"/>
    </head>
    <body>
        <div>
            <label for  = "username" class = "title"> Name: </label>
            <input type = "text"
                   id   = "username"
                   name = "username"/>
        </div>
        <div>
            <label for  = "email" class = "title"> Email: </label>
            <input type = "text"
                   id   = "email"
                   name = "email"/>
        </div>
        <div>
            <span  class = "title"> Gender: </span>
            <input  type = "radio"
