                     id  = "Male"
                    name = "Gender"><label for = "Male"> M </label>
            <input  type = "radio"
                     id  = "Female"
                    name = "Gender"><label for = "Female"> F </label>
        </div>
        <div>
            <input type  = "submit"
                   value = "Register">
        </div>
    </body>
</html>
div 
{
    width: 260px;
    padding: 10px;
}
.title 
{
    padding: 50px;
    text-align: center; 
}
[type="submit"]
{
  float: right;
}

Cursor Styles

cursor

cursor property allow you to control the the type of the mouse cursor that should be display to the users.

For example on a form you might set a hand cursor when the users hover it.

Here is the possible value that this property could use :

  • auto
  • crosshair
  • default
  • pointer
  • move
  • text
  • wait
  • help

You can specify your own image cursor using this property

url(‚Äùsource.gif‚Äù)

You should only use this value When you add a helpful information to the users in place that would expect the cursor. For example setting a crosshair cursor for link might confuse the users because users are not use for seeing it.

<head>
	<link href = "style.css"
				rel  = "stylesheet"
				type = "text/css"/>
</head>
<body>
	<a href = "example.html"> Hover Over me  </a>
</body>
a{
cursor: crosshair;
}

Web Developer Toolbar

Example Lists , Tables And Forms

This example demonstrates several of the CSS properties we have met in this chapter to control the presentation of lists , tables , and forms.

For the lists for free poetry events near the start of the page, the bullet points are styled with an image. The space between each list items is increased using the line-height property.

For the table, the gaps between cells are removed using the border-spacing property. Font-size is set for the <td> and the <th> elements as they do not inherit their size from parent elements.

The head of the table has a darker background, light text and a dark 2-pixel line between it and the table content. Rounded corners on the table header creating using the :first-child and :last-child pseudo classes ( for browsers that support rounded corner ) .

Alternate rows of the table have different shading, and texture is added with different borders on each side of the cell.

For the form, the related form controls are put in a <fieldset> element. The labels of the form controls on the left also use the float property to ensure that the forms controls are vertically aligned.

When the text boxes of the form receive focus or the user hovers over it. the background color and the border border color change. The submit buttons its has also been styled to make it clear where people should submit the forms. 

<!DOCTYPE html PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD XHTML 1.0 Strict//EN"
"https://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-strict.dtd">
<html>
    <head> 
        <title> Example Lists , Tables And Forms </title>
        <link href  = "CHAPTER14.X.css"  
               rel  = "stylesheet"
               type = "text/css"/>
    </head>
    <body>
        <h1> Poetry Workshops </h1>
        <p> We will be conducting a number of poetry workshops 
            and symposiums throught the year.
        </p>
        <p> Please note that the following events are free to members: </p>
        <ul>
            <li> A Poetic Perpective </li>
            <li> Walt Whitman at War </li>
            <li> Found Poems and Outsider Poetry </li>
        </ul>
        <table>
            <tr class = "header">
                <th> </th>
                <th> New York </th>
                <th> Chicago </th>
                <th> San Francisco </th>
            </tr>
            <tr>
                <td> A Peotic Perspective </td>
                <td> Sat, 4 Feb 2012 11am - 2pm </td>
                <td> Sat, 3 Mar 2012 11am - 2pm </td>
                <td> Sat, 17 Mar 2012 11am - 2pm </td>
            </tr>
            <tr class = "even">
                <td> Walt Whitman at War </td>
                <td> Sat, 7 Apr 2012 11am - 1pm </td>
                <td> Sat, 5 May 2012 11am - 1pm </td>
                <td> Sat, 19 May 2012 11am - 1pm </td>
            </tr>
            <tr>
                <td> Found Poems & Outsider Poetry </td>
                <td> Sat, 9 Jun 2012 11am - 2pm </td>
                <td> Sat, 7 Jul 2012 11am - 2pm </td>
                <td> Sat, 21 Jul 2012 11am - 2pm </td>
            </tr>
            <tr class = "even">
                <td> Natural Death: An Exploration </td>
                <td> Sat, 4 Aug 2012 11am - 4pm </td>
                <td> Sat, 8 Sep 2012 11am - 4pm </td>
                <td> Sat, 15 Sep 2012 11am - 4pm </td>
            </tr>
        </table>
        <div class = "head">
            <form action = "login.php" method = "post">
            <fieldset>
                <legend> Register your interest </legend>
                <div>
                    <label for  = "username" class = "title"> Your name: </label>
                    <input type = "text"
                           name = "username"
                           id   = "username"/>
                </div>
                <div>
                    <label for  = "email" class = "title"> Your email: </label>
                    <input type = "text"
                           name = "email"
                           id   = "email"/>
                </div>
                <div class = "centerhead">
                    <label for = "center" class = "title"> Your closest center: </label>
                    <select name = "center" id = "center">
                        <option value = "newyork" selected = "selected"> New York </option>
                        <option value = "chicago"> Chicago </option>
                        <option value = "sanfransico"> San Francisco </option>
                    </select>
                </div>
                <div class = "member">
                    <span class = "title1"> Are you a member? </span>
                    <span class = "yesno">
                    <input type = "radio"
                           name = "member"
                           value = "Yes"
                           id = "yes"> <label for = "yes"> Yes </label>
                    <input type = "radio"
                           name = "member"
                           value = "No"
                           id = "no"> <label for = "no"> No </label>
                    </span>
                </div>
            </fieldset >
            <div class = "button">
                <input type = "submit"
                       value = "Register"/>
            </div>
        </form>
        </div>
    </body>
</html>
body 
{
    font-family: monospace;
    color: rgb(144, 66, 66);
    font-size: 20px;
    font-weight: bold;
}
h1 
{
    font-weight: bold;
}
ul 
{
    list-style-type:circle;
    list-style-position: outside;
}
table 
{
    width: 900px;
    border-spacing:0px;
}
tr th:first-child
{
    width: 300px;
    border-top-left-radius: 10px;
}
tr th:last-child
{
    border-top-right-radius: 10px;
}
td 
{
    padding: 10px; 
}
tr th 
{
    border-collapse: collapse;
    border-width: thin;
    border-style: solid;
    border-color: rgb(0, 0, 0);
    font-weight: bold;
    text-transform: uppercase;
    text-shadow: 1px 1px;
}
tr td
{
    border-width: 1px;
    border-style: solid;
    border-color: rgb(154, 144, 144);
}
tr td:first-child
{
    font-weight: bold;
    text-shadow: 1px 1px;
}
tr.header 
{
    background-color: aqua;
}
tr 
{
    background-color:aquamarine;
}
tr.even 
{
    background-color: turquoise;
}
fieldset 
{
    width: 500px;
    height: 150px;
}
div.head 
{
    margin-top: 20px;
    width: 900px;
    height: 300px;
    padding: 10px;
}
.title 
{
    padding: 10px;
}
[type="text"] , #center
{
    float: right;
}
.centerhead 
{
    margin-top: 10px;
}
.member
{
    margin-top: 20px;
    width: 600px;
    text-align: right;
}
.button 
{
    width: 10%;
    padding: 10px;
    margin-left: 570px;
}
[type="submit"]
{
    padding: 10px;
    border-radius: 5px;
    background-color: rgb(153, 255, 0);
    color: rgb(255, 255, 255);
    font-weight: bold;
}
span.title1
{
    margin-left: 10px;
    float: left;
}
[type="submit"]:hover
{
    padding: 10px;
    border-radius: 5px;
    background-color: rgb(153, 255, 0);
    opacity: 0.7;
    color: rgb(255, 255, 255);
    font-weight: bold;
}

SUMMARY CHAPTER FOURTEEN : LISTS , TABLES AND FORMS

CHAPTER FIFTEEN : LAYOUT

In this chapter we are going to look at how to control each where element should sit on the page. And how to create a Attractive page layout.

This involve learning how designing for a screen can be different to designing for other medium ( such as print ) This chapter we will :

  • Explore the different way how to position element using normal flow , absolute positioning , relative positioning and float.
  • Discover how various device have different screen size and resolution. And how they affect the design process
  • Learn the different between the fix width and the liquid layout and how they are create.
  • Find out how designers use grid to make their page design look more professional.

Key Concept In Positioning Elements

Building Blocks

CSS treat every HTML elements as if it live inside it own box. This box can be either block level box or a inline level box.

Block level box start on the a new line and act as a main building block of any layout. While inline box flow between surrounding text. You can control how much space each box should take up by setting the width of the box ( sometime the height too ). To separate the box you can use the margin , border , padding and the background-color.

Block-level Element

Start on the new line <li> , <p> , <h1>

Inline Element

Flow between surrounding text <a> , <img> , <i>

Containing Element

If block element sit inside another block element. The outer block is known as the containing element or a parent element.

It‚Äôs common to group together element inside a <div> element. or other block element. For example you might group altogether element that form the header for the site ( such as the navigation and the logo ). The <div> element that contain group together element is then refer to The containing element or the parent element.

A box can be nested inside another block element. The containing Element or the parent element is direct parent of that element.

Controlling The Position Of Elements

CSS has following positioning scheme that allow you the layout of the page. Normal flow , relative positioning and absolute positioning. You can specify your positioning scheme using the position property in CSS. You can also float the element using the float property.

Normal Flow

Each Block level element start on the new line causing each element to appear lower down the page than the previous one. Even if you specify the width of the box that the space can take up two element sitting side by side they will not appear next to each other. This is the default behaviour unless you telling browser to do something else.

Relatives Positioning

This move an element from the position that would be in a normal flow. Shifting to left right top and bottom of where it would have been place. This does not affect the position of other surrounding elements. They sit in the position where they would be in normal flow.

Absolute Positioning

This position the element that in relation to its containing element. It‚Äôs taken out of the normal flow ( that move the position element that would be in the normal flow ) But it does not affect the position of the surround element. It simply ignore the space that would be taken up. Absolute Positioning element move when users scroll up and down the page.

To indicate Where the box should be position you may also use the box offset property that allow you to tell the browser how far the top or bottom and left or right it should be placed. ( You will meet these property when we introduce the positioning scheme in the future page ).

Fix positioning

This is the form of the absolute positioning elements that position relation to the main browser window oppose to the containing element. It is taken out of the normal flow ( move element that position would be in the normal flow ) and The Fix positioning element do not affect the position of the surrounding element And they do not move when the users scroll up or down the page.

Floating Element

Floating element allow you take the element from the normal flow and positioning that element to the far left or right of the containing box. The float element become the block level element around which allow other content can flow.

When you move the box from the normal flow the boxes can overlap. The z-index property allow you to control which box should appear on the top.

Normal Flow

position: static

In normal flow Block level element sit on the top of next one. Since this is default in which browsers treat this block level element so you do not need to specify CSS property to indicate that element would be in normal flow. But the syntax would be position: static.

I have not specify the width property for the heading so you can how the it stretch the width of the entire browsers by default.

The paragraph are restrict to 450 pixels wide so you can see how the element in the normal flow start on the new line even you do not specify the width to take up the full width of the browser.

<head>
   <link href = "example.css"
			   rel  = "stylesheet"
			   type = "text/css"/>
</head>
<body>
	<h1> The Evolution of The Bicycle </h1>
	<p> In 1817 Baron von Drais invented a walking machine that would 
	help him get around the royal gardens faster: two same-size in-line wheels, the front
	one steerable, mounted in a frame upon which you straddled. The device was propelled
	by pushing your feet against the ground, thus rolling yourself and the device forward
	in a sort of gliding walk. </p>
	
	<p> This machine became known as the Draisienne( or "hobby horse"). It was made entirely 
	of wood. This enjoyed a short lived popularity as a fad. not being practical for 
	transpotation
	in any other place than a well maintained pathway such as in a park or garden. </p>
	
	<p> The next appearence of a two-wheeled riding machine was in 1865, when pedals were
	applied directly to the front wheel. This machine was known as the velocipede ( meaning 
	"fast fool") as well as the "bone shaker," since it's wooden structure combined with 
	the cobblestone roads of the day made for an extremely uncomfortable ride. They also
	become a fad and indoor riding academies, similar to rollar rinks, could be found in
	large cities </p>
</body>	  
h1
{
	position: static;
	background-color: brown;
}
p 
{
	position: static;
	width: 450px;
}

Relative Positioning

position: relative

Relative Positioning move element in relation that would been in the normal flow.

For example you can move 10px lower than in would been in the normal flow. You can move to 20% to the right that would been in the normal flow.

You can indicate that element to be a relative positioning by using the position property and value should be relative.

Then you can specify the Box offset property ( bottom , top , left , right ) to indicate how far that element should move from where it would been in the normal flow.

To move the box up or down you can either use the box offset property which either top , bottom.

To move horizontally you can use the left or right.

The value of the Box offset property can be given as pixel , percentage and ems.

<head>
   <link href = "example.css"
			   rel  = "stylesheet"
			   type = "text/css"/>
</head>
<body>
	<h1> The Evolution of The Bicycle </h1>
	<p> In 1817 Baron von Drais invented a walking machine that would 
	help him get around the royal gardens faster: two same-size in-line wheels, the front
	one steerable, mounted in a frame upon which you straddled. The device was propelled
	by pushing your feet against the ground, thus rolling yourself and the device forward
	in a sort of gliding walk. </p>
	
	<p class = "relative"> This machine became known as the Draisienne( or "hobby horse"). It was made entirely 
	of wood. This enjoyed a short lived popularity as a fad. not being practical for 
	transpotation
	in any other place than a well maintained pathway such as in a park or garden. </p>
	
	<p> The next appearence of a two-wheeled riding machine was in 1865, when pedals were
	applied directly to the front wheel. This machine was known as the velocipede ( meaning 
	"fast fool") as well as the "bone shaker," since it's wooden structure combined with 
	the cobblestone roads of the day made for an extremely uncomfortable ride. They also
	become a fad and indoor riding academies, similar to rollar rinks, could be found in
	large cities </p>
</body>	  
h1
{
	position: static;
	background-color: brown;
}
relative
{
	position: relative;
	top: 10px;
	left: 100px;
}
p 
{
	position: static;
}

Absolute Positioning

position: absolute

When a position property is given a value absolute. The box is taken out of the normal flow and do not affect the position of other element on the page ( They act like it‚Äôs not there ).

The box offset properties ( top , bottom , left , right ) specify where the element should appear in relation to the containing elements.

In this example the heading has position at the top of the page. And 500pixel from its left edge and the width of the heading has been set to 250pixel wide.

The width has also been applied to <p> element. To prevent the text from overlapping and become unreadable.

By default most browser add margin to the top of the heading this is way there is gap between the top of the browsers and the containing <h1> element. To remove the margin you could add this following code to the <h1> element style rule.

<head>
   <link href = "example.css"
			   rel  = "stylesheet"
			   type = "text/css"/>
</head>
<body>
	<h1> The Evolution of The Bicycle </h1>
	<p> In 1817 Baron von Drais invented a walking machine that would 
	help him get around the royal gardens faster: two same-size in-line wheels, the front
	one steerable, mounted in a frame upon which you straddled. The device was propelled
	by pushing your feet against the ground, thus rolling yourself and the device forward
	in a sort of gliding walk. </p>
	
	<p> This machine became known as the Draisienne( or "hobby horse"). It was made entirely 
	of wood. This enjoyed a short lived popularity as a fad. not being practical for 
	transpotation
	in any other place than a well maintained pathway such as in a park or garden. </p>
	
	<p> The next appearence of a two-wheeled riding machine was in 1865, when pedals were
	applied directly to the front wheel. This machine was known as the velocipede ( meaning 
	"fast fool") as well as the "bone shaker," since it's wooden structure combined with 
	the cobblestone roads of the day made for an extremely uncomfortable ride. They also
	become a fad and indoor riding academies, similar to rollar rinks, could be found in
	large cities </p>
</body>	
h1 
{
  position: absolute;
  left: 500px;
  width: 250px;
  margin: 0px;
}
p 
{
	width: 250px;
}

Fixed Positioning

position: fixed

Fixed Positioning is a type of Absolute Positioning. That required a position property to have a value of fixed.

It position elements in relation to browser window therefore when users scroll down to the page that elements stay in exactly same place. It‚Äôs good idea to try this example on your browsers to see the effect.

To control where the fix box appear in relation to the main browsers window the offset property will be used.

In this example the heading has position to the top left corner when the users scroll down the page the paragraph disappear behind the heading.

The <p> element are in the normal the normal flow and do ignore the space that the <h1> element taken up. Therefore the top-margin has been used to push the first <p> element below where the fixed position <h1> element is sitting.

Overlapping Elements

z-index

When you use the relative , absolute , fixed positioning box can overlap. If the box do overlap The element that appear later in the HTML code will sit over the top of those element that sit earlier in the page.

If you want to control which element sit on top you can use the z-index property. The value of this property is the number. The higher the number the closer the element is to the front. For example the element with the z-index of 10 will appear over the top of the element that have z-index of 5.

The example below look similar to the one on the previous page but it use the relative positioning element for the <p> element. Because paragraph is a relative positioning they will appear over the heading element ( since we mention earlier that if the element use the relative , absolute , fixed positioning ) the new element will appear over the top of the earlier element on the page. as the users scroll down the page. To ensure that heading stay exactly at the same place or appear over the paragraph you can use the z-index property on the <h1> element.

The z-index property is sometime refer as a stacking context ( as if the block have been on top of each other on a z axis ) . If you familiar with a desktop publishing package it‚Äôs equivalent to the sent to back or bring to front feature.

<head>
   <link href = "example.css"
			   rel  = "stylesheet"
			   type = "text/css"/>
</head>
<body>
	<h1> The Evolution of The Bicycle </h1>
	<p> In 1817 Baron von Drais invented a walking machine that would 
	help him get around the royal gardens faster: two same-size in-line wheels, the front
	one steerable, mounted in a frame upon which you straddled. The device was propelled
	by pushing your feet against the ground, thus rolling yourself and the device forward
	in a sort of gliding walk. </p>
	
	<p> This machine became known as the Draisienne( or "hobby horse"). It was made entirely 
	of wood. This enjoyed a short lived popularity as a fad. not being practical for 
	transpotation
	in any other place than a well maintained pathway such as in a park or garden. </p>
	
	<p> The next appearence of a two-wheeled riding machine was in 1865, when pedals were
	applied directly to the front wheel. This machine was known as the velocipede ( meaning 
	"fast fool") as well as the "bone shaker," since it's wooden structure combined with 
	the cobblestone roads of the day made for an extremely uncomfortable ride. They also
	become a fad and indoor riding academies, similar to rollar rinks, could be found in
	large cities </p>
</body>	
p
{
	position: relative;
	bottom: 100px;
	z-index: 5px;
}
h1
{
	z-index: 10px;
	position: static;
}

Floating Element

float

The float property allow you to take the element from the normal flow and positioning it to the far left or right of the containing element as possible.

Anything else that sit inside that containing element will flow around the element that have been float.

When you use the float property you should use the width property to indicate how wide that float element should be. If you do not the result will be inconsistent the box will take up the full width of the containing box. Just like in the normal flow.

In this example below the <blockquote> element contain a quotation and the containing element of this <blockquote> element is a <body> element.

The <blockquote> element have been float to the right and paragraph that follow that quote element will flow around that float element.

<!DOCTYPE html PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD XHTML 1.0 Strict//EN"
"https://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-strict.dtd">
<head>
    <title>
        Float Elements 
    </title>
    <link href = "CHAPTER15.5.css"
          rel  = "stylesheet"
          type = "text/css">
    <body>
        <h1> The Evolution of the Bicycle </h1>
        <p>  In 1817 Baron von Drais invented a walking 
             machine that would be around the royal gardens 
             faster: two same-size in-line wheels, the front 
             one steerable, mounted in a frame upon which you straddled.
             <blockquote>
                "Life is like riding a a bicycle. To keep your balance
                you must keep moving. " - Albert Einstein.
             </blockquote>
             the device was propelled by pushing your feet against the ground.
             , thus rolling yourself and the device forward in a sort of gliding 
             walk.
        </p>
          <p>  The machine became known as the Draisienne ( or "hobby horse"). It was made entirely of wood.
             This enjoyed a short lived popularity as a fad, not being practical for transportation in any 
             other place than a well maintain pathway such as in park or garden.
        </p>
        <p>  The next appearance of a two-wheeled riding machine was in 1865, when pedals were applied directly to 
             the front wheel. This machine was known as the velocipede ( meaning "fast foot") as well as the "bone shaker,"
             since its wooden structure combined with the cobblestone roads of day made for an extremely 
             uncomfortable ride. They also became a fad and indoor riding academeies, similar to 
             roller rinks, could be found in large cities.
        </p>
        <p>  In 1870 the first all-metal machine appeared. (Prior to this, metallurgy was not advance enough to 
             provide metal which was strong enough to make small, light parts out of.) The pedals were attached 
             directly to the front wheel with no freewheeling mechanism. Solid rubber tires and the long spokes 
             of the large front wheel provided a much smoother ride than its predecessor. 
        </p>
        <p>  The front wheels became larger and larger as makers realized that the larger the wheel, the farther you could 
             travel with one rotation of the pedals. For that reason, you would puchase a wheel as large as your leg 
             lendth would allow. This machine was the first one to be called a bicycle("two wheel"). These bicycles enjoyed a 
             great popularity during the 1880s among young men of means. ( They cost an average worker six month's pay. ) 
        </p>
        <p>
             Because the rider sat so high above the center of gravity, if 
             the front wheel was stopped by a stone or rut in the road, or the sudden
             emergence of a dog, the entire apparatus rotated forward on its front axie 
             and the rider, with his legs trapped under the handlebars, was dropped unceremoniously
             on his head. Thus the term "taking a header" came into being.  
        </p>
    </body>
</hea
h1 
{
    font-size: 64px;
    width: 1000px;
    font-family: monospace;
}
blockquote 
{
    width: 300px;
    border: medium double black;
    padding: 10px;
    float: right;
}

Using Float To Place Elements Elements Side-By-Side

A lot of layout place box next to each other. The float property are commonly used to achieve this.

When element are float. The height of the box can affect where the following element sit.

In this example you can see six paragraph each of which have a width and the float property set.

The fourth paragraph doesn‚Äôt go across left edge of page as one you might expected it rather sit under the third paragraph.

This is because the fourth paragraph has space under the third paragraph and it cannot go any further to the left because the second paragraph is in the way.

Setting the height of the paragraph to be the same height as the taller paragraph would solve this issue. But it would not suited to the real world design where the text in the paragraph or column can be vary. You should use the clear property discuss on the next page instead.

<!DOCTYPE html PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD XHTML 1.0 Strict//EN"
"https://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-strict.dtd">
<html>
    <head> 
        <title> Using Float to sit side by side </title>
        <link href = "CHAPTER15.6.css"
              type = "text/css"
              rel  = "stylesheet"/>
    </head>
    <body>
        <h1> The Evolution of the Bicycle </h1>
        <p>  In 1870 Baron von Drais invented a walking machine that would help him get around
             the royal gardens faster.    
        </p>
        <p>  The device know as the Draisienne ( or "hobby horse") was made of wood, and 
             propelled by pushing your feet on the ground in 
             a gliding movement.
        </p>
        <p>  It was not seen as suitable for any place other than 
             a well maintained pathway.
        </p>
        <p>  In 1865, the velocipede (meaning "fast foot") attached 
             pedals to the front wheel, but its sodden structure made it 
             extremely uncomfortable.
        </p>
        <p>  In 1870 the first all-metal machine appeared. The pedals were attached directly to the 
             front wheel.
        </p>
        <p>  Solid rubber tires and the long spokes of the large front wheel 
             provided a much smoother ride than its predecessor. 
        </p>
    </body>
</html>
h1 
{
    font-family: monospace;
    font-size: 50px;
    width: 900px;
}
p 
{
    width: 150px;
    background-color: antiquewhite;
    float: left;
}

Clearing Floats

clear

The clear property allow you say no to element ( contain within the same containing element ). that should touch the left hand side or the right hand side of the box. It can take this following value:

left

The left hand side of the box should not touch any other element in the same containing element.

right

The right hand side of the box should not touch any other element in the same containing element.

both

The left hand side and the right hand side of the box should not touch any other element in the same containing element.

none

The left hand side and the right hand side of the box can touch other element in the same containing element.

In this example the paragraph with a class attribute whose value is clear. The CSS rule have applied to a class attribute whose value is clear using the clear property indicate that left hand side of the box should not touch other element in the same containing element. And Therefore the paragraph can move further down without touching other element left hand side.h

<!DOCTYPE html PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD XHTML 1.0 Strict//EN"
"https://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-strict.dtd">
<html>
    <head> 
        <title> Clear Property </title>
        <link href  = "CHAPTER15.7.css"
               rel  = "stylesheet"
               type = "text/css"/>
    </head>
    <body>
        <h1> The Evolution of the Bicycle </h1>
        <p>  In 1817 Baron von Drais invented a walking machine
             that would help get around the royal gardens faster.     
        </p>
        <p class = "clear">  The device know as the Draisienne ( or "hobby hourse")
             was made of wood, and propelled by pushing your feet on the ground 
             in a gliding movement.
        </p>
        <p>  It was not seen as suitable for any place other than a well 
             maintained pathway. 
        </p>
        <p class = "clear">  In 1865, the velocipede (meaning "fast foot") attached pedals 
             to the front wheel, but its wooden structure made it extremely uncomfortable.
        </p>
        <p>  In 1870 the first all-metal machine appeared. The pedals were attached directly 
             to the front wheel. 
        </p>
        <p>  Solid rubber tires and the long spokes of the large front wheel provided a 
             much smoother ride than its predecessor.
        </p>
    </body>
</html>
h1 
{
    font-family: monospace;
    font-size: 55px;
    background-color: beige;
}
p 
{
    width: 220px;
    float: left;
    padding: 10px;
    background-color: blanchedalmond;
}
.clear 
{
    clear: left;
}

Parents Of Float Element: Problem

If the containing element only contain a float element. Some browsers will treat if it was a 0 pixels tall.

As you can see on this example below We assign 1px border to the containing element has collapse. The box just look like a two pixels line.

<!DOCTYPE html PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD XHTML 1.0 Strict//EN"
"https://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-strict.dtd">
<html>
    <head>
        <title> Parents of Float Element </title>
        <link href = "CHAPTER15.8.css"
              rel  = "stylesheet"
              type = "text/css">
    </head>
    <body>
        <h1> The Evolution of the Bicycle </h1>
        <div>
        <p>  In 1817 Baron von Drais invented a walking 
                 machine thta would help him get around the 
                 royal gardens faster.
            </p>
            <p>  The device know as the Draisienne ( or "hobby horse")
                 was made of wood, and propelled by pushing your feet 
                 on the ground in a gliding movement.
            </p>
            <p>  It was not seen as suitable for any place other than a well 
                 maintained pathway.
            </p>
            <p class = "clear">
                 In 1865, the velocipede ( meaning "fast foot") attached pedals
                 to the front wheel, but its wooden structure made it extremely uncomfortable.   
            </p>
            <p>  In 1870 the first all-metal machine appeared. The pedals were attached directly 
                 to the front wheel.
            </p>
            <p>  Solid rubber tires and the long spokes of the large front wheel provided a much smoother 
                 ride than its predecessor.
            </p>
        </div>
    </body>
</html>
h1 
{
    font-family: monospace;
    font-size: 72px;
    color:brown;
}
p 
{
    width: 150px;
    float: left;
    padding: 10px;
    background-color: azure;

}
.clear 
{
    padding: 10px;
    clear: left;
    background-color: antiquewhite;
}
div 
{
    border: 1px solid red;
}

Parents Of Floated Elements: Solution

Traditionally developer do get around with this by adding extra element after the last float element ( inside the containing element ) . A CSS rule would apply to that extra element setting the clear property with a value of both. But this mean that the extra element was add to HTML just to fix the height of the containing element.

More recently developer have opt to use the purely CSS base solution This mean that we do not need add extra element after the last float element. The pure CSS solution add two CSS rule to containing element ( The containing element in this example is <div> element ).

The two CSS rule would be :

  • A overflow property with a given value of auto
  • A width property set to 100% 
<!DOCTYPE html PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD XHTML 1.0 Strict//EN"
"https://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-strict.dtd">
<html>
    <head>
        <title> Parents of Float Element </title>
        <link href = "CHAPTER15.9.css"
              rel  = "stylesheet"
              type = "text/css">
    </head>
    <body>
        <h1> The Evolution of the Bicycle </h1>
        <div id = "containing">
        <p>  In 1817 Baron von Drais invented a walking 
            machine thta would help him get around the 
            royal gardens faster.
        </p>
            <p>  The device know as the Draisienne ( or "hobby horse")
                 was made of wood, and propelled by pushing your feet 
                 on the ground in a gliding movement.
            </p>
            <p>  It was not seen as suitable for any place other than a well 
                 maintained pathway.
            </p>
            <p class = "clear">
                 In 1865, the velocipede ( meaning "fast foot") attached pedals
                 to the front wheel, but its wooden structure made it extremely uncomfortable.   
            </p>
            <p>  In 1870 the first all-metal machine appeared. The pedals were attached directly 
                 to the front wheel.
            </p>
            <p>  Solid rubber tires and the long spokes of the large front wheel provided a much smoother 
                 ride than its predecessor.
            </p>
        </div>
    </body>
</html>
h1 
{
    font-family: monospace;
    background-color: aliceblue;
    font-size: 55px;
}
p 
{
    width: 150px;
    float: left;
    padding:10px;
    background-color: antiquewhite;
}
.clear 
{
    clear: left;
}
#containing
{
    border: 10px solid red;
    background-color: beige;
    overflow: auto;
    width: 50%;
}

Creating Multi-Column Layouts With Floats

Many Webpage use column in their design. This column can be create by using the <div> element. And this following CSS property are use to position this column next to each other:

width

Set the width of the column.

float

position the column to sit next to each other.

margin

Separate the gap between each of the column

A two layout like this shown below would need two <div>element to represent each column. One <div> element for the content of the page and another one <div> element for the sidebars.

Inside the <div> element it can contain a image , paragraph , text ,heading and other <div> element.

<!DOCTYPE html PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD XHTML 1.0 Strict//EN"
"https://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-strict.dtd">
<html>
    <head>
        <title> The Evolution of the Bicycle </title>
        <link href = "CHAPTER15.10.css"
              rel  = "stylesheet"
              type = "text/css">
    </head>
    <body>
        <h1> The Evolution of the Bicycle </h1>
        <div class = "containing">
            <div class = "column1"> 
                <h2> The First Bicycle </h2>
                <p>  In 1817 Baron von Drais invented a walking machine that would 
                     help him get around help him get around the royal gardens faster:
                     two same-size in-line wheels, the front one steerable, mounted in a frame 
                     upon which straddled. The device was propelled by pushing your 
                     feet against the ground, thus rolling yourself and the device forward 
                     in a sort of gliding walk. 
                </p>
                <p>
                     The machine became known as the Draisienne ( or "hobby horse"). It was made entirely 
                     of wood. This enjoyed a short lived popularity as a fad, not being pratical for tranportation 
                     in any other place than a well maintained pathway such as in a park or graden.
                </p>
                <h2> Further Innovations </h2>
                <p>  The next appearence of a two-wheeled riding machine was in 1865, when pedals were 
                     applied directly to the front wheel. This machine was known as the velocipede ( meaning "fast foot") as 
                     well as the "bone shaker," since its wooden structure combined with the cobblestone roads of the day made 
                     for an extremely uncomfortable ride they also became a fad and indoor riding academies, similar to roller rinks, 
                     could be found in large cities.    
                </p>
                <p>
                     In 1870 the first all-metal machine appeared. ( Pior to this metallurgy was not advanced enough to provide metal which 
                     was strong enough to make small, light parts out of.) The pedals were attached directly to the front wheel with no freewheeling 
                     mechanism. Solid rubber tires and the long spokes of the large front wheel provided a much smoother ride than its predecessor. 
                </p>
            </div>
            <div class = "column2">
                <h3> Bicycle Timeline </h3>
                <ul>
                    <li> 1817: Draisienne </li>
                    <li> 1865: Velocipede </li>
                    <li> 1870: Hight-wheel bicycle </li>
                    <li> 1876: Hight-wheel safety  </li>
                    <li> 1885: Hard-tired safety </li>
                    <li> 1888: Pneumatic safety </li>
                </ul>
            </div>
        </div>
    </body>
</html>
.containing 
{
    overflow: auto;
    width: 2000px;
    border: solid red;
}
h1 , h2 , h3 
{
    font-family: monospace;
    font-size:50px;
    color: brown;
    background-color: antiquewhite;
}
.column1 
{
    width: 300px;
    float: left;
    margin: 10px;
    padding: 10px;
}
.column2 
{
    width: 250px;
    float: left;
    margin: 50px;
    position: relative;
    bottom: 40px;
}

Similarly a three column can be create by floating 3 column ( represent by the <div> element ) next to each other shown below. 

<!DOCTYPE html PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD XHTML 1.0 Strict//EN"
"https://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-strict.dtd">
<html>
    <head>
        <title> Creating Multi-Column Layouts With Floats Three Columns </title>
        <link href = "CHAPTER15.11.css"
              rel  = "stylesheet"
              type = "text/css"/>
    </head>
    <body>
        <div class = "containing">
            <h1> The Evolution of the Bicycle </h1>
            <div class = "column1">
                <h2> The First Bicycle </h1>
                <p>  In 1817 Baron von Drais invented a 
                     walking machine that would help him get 
                     around the royal gardens faster: two same-size
                     in-line wheels, the front one steerable, mounted in 
                     a frame upon which you straddle. The device was propelled 
                     by pushing your feet against the ground, thus rolling yourself and the 
                     device forward in a sort of gliding walk.
                </p>
                <p>
                     The machine became knownas the Draisienne (or "hobby horse"). It was
                     made entirely of wood. This enjoyed a short lived popularity as a fad, not 
                     being pratical for transportation in any other place than a well maintained pathway 
                     such as in a park or garden. 
                </p>
            </div>
            <div class = "column2"> 
                <h2> Further Innovations </h1>
                <p>  The next appearence of a two-wheeled riding machine was in 
                     1865, when pedals were applied directly to the front wheel. This 
                     machine was known as the velocipede ( meaning "fast foot") as well as 
                     the "boner shaker," since its wooden structure combined with the cobblestone roads 
                     of the day made for an extremely uncomfortable ride. They also became a fad and indoor riding 
                     academies, similar to rollar rink, could be found in large cities.
                </p>
                <p>
                     In 1870 the first all-metal machine appeared. ( Pior to this, metallurgy was 
                     not advance enough to make smalllight parts out of.) The pedals were attached 
                     directly to the front wheel with no freewheeling mechanism. Solid rubber 
                     tires and the long spokes of the large front wheel provided a much smoother ride 
                     than its predecessor.
                </p>
            </div>
            <div class =  "column3">
                <h2> Bicycle Timeline </h2>
                <ul>
                    <li> 1817: Draisienne </li>
                    <li> 1865: Velocipede </li>
                    <li> 1870: High-wheel bicycle </li>
                    <li> 1876: High-wheel safety </li>
                    <li> 1885: Hard-tired safety </li>
                    <li> 1888: Pneumatic safety </li>
                </ul>
            </div>
        </div>
    </body>
</html>
h1 
{
    background-color: antiquewhite;
    color: brown;
    font-family:monospace;
    font-size: 50px;
    margin: 10px;
    padding: 10px;
}
h2 
{
    color:darkblue;
}
.column1 , .column2 , .column3
{
    width: 250px;
    float: left;
    margin: 20px 10px;
}
.containing
{
    overflow: auto;
    width: 90%;
    padding: 10px;
    margin: 10px 20px;
}

Screen Sizes

Different visitor visit your site in different size screen that show different amount of information. So you need a design that can be able to work in range of different size screen.

When designing for a print you always know the size of the piece of paper that design print on. However when designing for web you face a unique challenge because users have a different size screen visit your site.

Since computer have been sold publicly. The screen size have been steadily increasing Some people might view your site that have 13inch monitor and other people might view your site that have 27+ inch monitor.

The size of the users screen can affect how big they open the window and how much page they could see. There are increasing number of handheld device ( mobile phone , tablet ) that have smaller screens.

Screen Resolution

Resolution is the number of dot that the screen show per inch. Some device have higher resolution than the desktop computer. Most computer allow users to adjust the resolution for their screen.

Most computer will let the owner to adjust the resolution of the display or the number of the pixel that are show on the screen. In this example above you can see the option that users to change the size screen from 720 x 480 pixels up to 1280 x 800 pixels.

It‚Äôs interesting to note that the higher resolution the text would appear smaller. Mobile device have the screen that are higher resolution than most computer counterparts.

Page Sizes

Because screen size and display resolution vary so much. Web designer often try to create a page around 960 - 1000 pixel wide. ( Because a lot of users often see design in this wide on their screens ).

Judging the height that people would likely to see on the screen without having to scroll down the page is much harder. In several years Web designer assume that users would see the top 570 - 600 pixels without having scrolling down to the page and some try to fit in some key message in this area ( fearing that people would not scrolling down the page ).

As screen sized have increase and the handheld device have been very popular. The area that the users would see is far more variable ( it could change depending on the screen size that the reason that web designer assume the height the users would see without scrolling down ).

The area that you would see without scrolling down the page is often refer as being Above the fold ( A term Newspaper originally coined to describe a area of the front page that you would see if the paper were fold. )

It‚Äôs recognized that if someone are interest in the content of the page that are likely to scroll down to page to see more content. Having said which usability study shown that visitor visit the site judging the page in less than one second. So it‚Äôs still important to let the new visitor visit your page know that the site are relevant to them.

As result most designer try to let the users know what the site about within the top 570 - 600 pixel wide. As well as hint at more content below this point. But do not cram ( adding too much information ) in the top 570 - 600 pixel.

At the time of the author writing this there is a growing trend for people to create adaptive or responsive design that could change depending on the size of the screen.

Fixed Width Layouts

Fixed width layout Design do not change the size as the users increasing or decreasing the size of the main browsers. Measurement tent to be given in pixels.

Advantages

  • Pixels are accurate at controlling size and position the element.
  • The designer has far greater control over the appearence and position of item on the page than with a liquid layout.
  • The images size remain the same relative to the rest of the page.

Disadvantages

  • You can end up with a big gaps around the edge of the page.
  • If the users is much higher resolution than the designer. The page will look smaller and the text can be small making it harder to read.
  • If a users increase the font-size of the page the text might not fit into the a box containing it.
  • The design work best for device that have the site or resolution similar to the desktop or laptop computer. ( it might mean like this if the designer built it in desktop computer that design is best on the device and you will something that designer are expected. If that device got similar screen size or similar resolution or it could mean if it display best for the desktop or laptop computer In order for the device to display like those computer . That device must have a similar size screen and display resolution.
  • The page often take up more vertical space than liquid layout with the same content.

Liquid Layout

Liquid layout design stretch and contrast ( narrow ) as the users increasing or decreasing the size of the main browsers window. Measurement tent to be given in percentage.

Advantages

  • Page expand to fill in the entire users browser window. So there are no space on the larger screen.
  • If a users window is small page can contrast to fit in without users to scroll to the site.
  • The design is tolerant of user setting the font size is larger than the designer intended because the page can stretch.

Disadvantages

  • If you do not control the width of the section of the page design can look different then you intend with a unexpected gaps around certain element or items squashed together.
  • If the users use a wide window the text can be very long make them harder to read
  • If the users use a narrow window a word may be squashed together and you end up with a few words on each line.
  • If a fixed item ( such as images ) is in a box that is smaller containing that images ( the box is small since users make the browser window narrow ) the images can be overflow over the text.

Because liquid layout stretch the entire width of the browser window in result the line of text become very long making it harder to read. So some liquid layout only let part on the page to expand and contrast and other part on the page to have a minimum and maximum width.

A Fixed Width Layout

To create a fix width layout the width of the main box usually specify in pixels ( and sometime the height the height too ).

Here you can see several <div> element that have a class and id attribute to indicate their purpose on the page ( the div also use to create a column since page contain multiple column for their design ).

In the book like this the result both for the fix width layout and the liquid layout look similar. To get the feel of them you can view it on your main browser window and see how they react when you adjust the browsers window.

The fixed width layout stay exact at the same size meaning that the width of the main box that are specify in pixels will stay exactly the same size no matter what the size of the browsers window whereas the liquid layout stretch and shrink to fit in the screen ( since it relation to the size browsers window. )

The HTML is same for both fixed width layout and liquid layout while fixed width layout example is this page while the liquid layout discuss next page.

In this example below the rule for the <body> element is use to fixed the width of the page at 960 pixels wide. And it‚Äôs center by the setting the left and the right margin to auto.

The main box on the page have margin 10px to create gap between each.

The navigation feature and footer panel stretch the width of the containing box ( which is instance is <body> element ) so we no need to specify the width for them.

The three column are 300pixel wide and use the float property to allow them sit next to each other.

Sometimes an extra HTML element is use to contain the content of the page rather then the fixed the width of the <body> element. To allow the background color of the browsers window is different from the content that stay in the main fix the width box.

<!DOCTYPE html PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD XHTML 1.0 Strict//EN"
"https://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-strict.dtd">
<html>
    <head>
        <title> Fixed Width Layout </title>
        <link href = "CHAPTER15.12.css"
              rel  = "stylesheet"
              type = "text/css"/>
    </head>
    <body>
        <h1> Logo </h1>
        <div class = "navigation">
            <ul>
                <li><a href = "#"> Home </a></li>
                <li><a href = "#"> Products </a></li>
                <li><a href = "#"> Service </a></li>
                <li><a href = "#"> About </a></li>
                <li><a href = "#"> Contact </a></li>
            </ul>
        </div>
        <div class = "feature">
            <p> Feature </p>
        </div>
        <div class = "column1">
            <p> Column One </p>
        </div>
        <div class = "column2">
            <p> Column Two </p>
        </div>
        <div class = "column3">
            <p> Column Three </p>
        </div>
        <div class = "footer">
            <p> &copy Copyright 2011 </p>
        </div>
    </body>
</html>
body 
{
    width: 960px;
    margin-left: auto;
    margin-right: auto;
    text-align: center;
}
h1 
{
    background-color: antiquewhite;
    font-family: monospace;

}
li 
{
    display: inline;
    padding: 20px;
}
li > a 
{
    color: black;
    text-decoration: none;
}
.navigation 
{
    height: 20px;
    padding-top: 10px;
    padding-bottom: 30px;
    background-color: antiquewhite;
}
.feature 
{
    background-color: antiquewhite;
    margin-top: 15px;
    padding: 50px;
}
.column1 , .column2 , .column3
{
    width: 300px;
    float: left;
    margin-top: 10px;
    background-color: antiquewhite;
    margin-right: 20px;
}
.footer 
{
    margin-top: 80px;
    background-color: antiquewhite;
    padding: 30px;
}

A Liquid Layout

A liquid layout use percentage to specify the width ( sometime the height ) of each box. So the design will stretch to fit in the size of the users screen.

If you use this example on the your browsers window remember to make your browser window smaller or larger.

There is a rule on the <body> element set to the width of the page to 90% so there is a gaps between the right hand side and the left hand side of the browsers window and main content.

The three column have given a margin of 1% and the width of 31.3% Add up to 99.9% of the width of the <body> element. So some browsers will not perfectly align the right hand side of the third column with other elements on the page.

The <div> element that hold the navigation , feature and footer will stretch to fill the width of the containing element ( in this example <body> element ) . They also given a margin of 1% to help them align with the column.

If you imagine the browser window is wide or narrow. The line of text can become very long and short.

This is where min-width and max-width property help to create boundaries within which layout can stretch. ( Although Internet Explorer 7 was the first version to support this property ) .

<!DOCTYPE html PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD XHTML 1.0 Strict//EN"
"https://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-strict.dtd">
<html>
    <head>
        <title> Fixed Width Layout </title>
        <link href = "CHAPTER15.13.css"
              rel  = "stylesheet"
              type = "text/css"/>
    </head>
    <body>
        <h1> Logo </h1>
        <div class = "navigation">
            <ul>
                <li><a href = "#"> Home </a></li>
                <li><a href = "#"> Products </a></li>
                <li><a href = "#"> Service </a></li>
                <li><a href = "#"> About </a></li>
                <li><a href = "#"> Contact </a></li>
            </ul>
        </div>
        <div class = "feature">
            <p> Feature </p>
        </div>
        <div class = "column1">
            <p> Column One </p>
        </div>
        <div class = "column2">
            <p> Column Two </p>
        </div>
        <div class = "column3">
            <p> Column Three </p>
        </div>
        <div class = "footer">
            <p> &copy Copyright 2011 </p>
        </div>
    </body>
</html>
body 
{
    width: 90%;
    text-align: center;
    margin-top: 0px;
    margin-right: auto;
    margin-bottom: 0px;
    margin-left: auto;
}
h1 
{
    background-color: antiquewhite;
    font-family: monospace;
    margin: 1% 1% 1% 1%;
}
.navigation 
{
    background-color: bisque;
    width: 94.1%;
    padding: 2%;
    margin-left: 1%;
}
li 
{
    display: inline;
    margin: 1%;
}
li > a 
{
    color: black;
    text-decoration: none;
}
.feature 
{
    background-color: antiquewhite;
    margin: 1%;
    padding: 9%;
}
.column1 , .column2 , .column3 
{
    float: left;
    background-color: bisque;
    margin: 1%;
    width: 31.3%;
}
.footer 
{
    background-color: antiquewhite;
    margin-top: 9%;
    padding: 1%;
    width: 96%;
    margin-left: 1%;
}

Layout Grids

Composition in any visual art ( Such as Design , Painting or Photograph ) is a placement or arrangement of Visual Element And how they organize on the page. Many designer use grid structure to help them position items on the page. It‚Äôs Same is true for web designer.

Below you can see a set of vertical line that superimposed ( lay or place ) over the top of the page of a newspaper website that show how the page is design according to the grid. The grid is called 960 pixels grid that are widely use by web designer.

Grids set a consistent proportions ( a part that relation to the whole ) and space between item which help to create a professional looking design.

If you flick through the page of this book you can see them too that have been construct according to the grid. ( Comprising Three column ).

As you can see on the next 389 - 390 You can create many layout using this one versatile grid.

While grid might seems like a restriction. In Actual facts it

  • Create a continuity ( Something that stay continue for a long period of time without being changed ) Between different pages that may use different design.
  • Help the users to predict where to find the information on various( more than one ) page.
  • It make easier for you to add a new content to the site in consistent way.
  • Help people collaborate on the design of the site in consistent way.

Example Grid

Possible Layouts: 960 Pixel Wide 12 Column Grid

As you know you can create many different layout using only on grid. As you can see above there the possible layout that you create in a 960pixels wide 12 column grid. The column grid are shown in gray have a width of 60 pixels. Each of grid column have a margin set to 10pixel which mean that the grid have 20pixel gaps between each column 10px to the left hand side and 10px to the right hand side. ( While you can create your own layout in 960pixel wide 12 column grid but here is the possible layout example. ).

CSS Frameworks

CSS frameworks aim to make your life easier by providing the code for common task. Such as Creating layout grid, Styling form and Creating printer friendly version of the page and so on. You can include the CSS frameworks code in your projects rather then writing your own CSS from scratch.

Advantages

  • They save you from repeatedly writing code for the same tasked.
  • They will have been tested across different browser version ( which help avoid browsers bugs ).

Disadvantages

  • They often require you to use class name in your HTML code that only control the presentation of the page rather then describe it own content. ( it mean that we often use class to indicate the the purpose of this content when doing the CSS framework that class is the control presentation of the page rather then describe its own content ) .
  • In order to satisfy the wide variety of need they contain more code than you need for a particular web page ( commonly refer to as code ‚Äúbloat‚Äù ).

Introducing The 960.GS CSS Framework

  • One of the most popular way to use a CSS framework is in creating grid to layout the page. There are several grid framework out there but the one that we looking over the next few page is called 960 grid system. Available at ( www.960.gs ).

    960 grid system provide you a stylesheet that you can include in your HTML code once you link your page to that stylesheet. You can provide a appropriate class in your HTML code and it will create multiple column layout for you. In 960.gs website also provide you a template that allow you to download to help you help for the page that using 12 column grid ( In additional There is variation on grid that use 16 column ).

  • To create a 12 column grid. An element that contain the content of the page is given a class attribute whose value is container_12 ( since we want our content of page is using 12 column grid ) This will set the content of the page to be 960 pixels wide ( width ) and indicate that we are using 12 column grid.
  • There are different class for block ( <div> that represent column ) that take up 1 , 2 , 3 , 4 up to 12 column of a grid. Each of block use a class name such as grid_3 ( that indicate that the block will stretched over three column ) , grid_4 ( that indicate that the block will stretch over 4 column ) and so on through to grid_12 ( that indicate that the block will stretch the full width of the page since our page is using 12 column of a grid using grid_12 the block will stretch over 12 column which is the full width of the page ). These column are all float to the left. And there is a 10 margin to the left and right of each one.

There are several other grid-based CSS frameworks available online, such as those at: blueprintcss.org , lessframework.com , developer.yahoo.com/yui/grids .

Using The 960.GS Grid

Below you can see a sample layout of the page just the same as fixed width page example. On the next page you will try to recreate this using the 960.GS. Instead of writing your own CSS to control layouts. You will also need to add class to the HTML code to indicate how wide each section is.

A Grid-Based Layout Using 960.GS

Let take a look at HTML page that have been mark up to use the 960.gs ( grid system ).

You can see below that we include the CSS for the grid using the <link> element inside the <head> element of the page.

The style that we are writing for ourself are shown below.

The 960_12_col.css stylesheet contain all the rule that we need to control the grid layout. The HTML use the class name :

container_12 this act like a container of the page and indicate that we are using the 12 column grid.

clearfix ensure that the browser know the height of the containing box because the containing box only contain a float element.

grid_12 create a block that is twelve column wide.

grid_4 create a block that is four column wide.

The 960.gs style sheet has taken care of the layout. Creating a correct width column and space between them Therefore the only rule that we need to add in this page is

  • Control the font and position of the text in the box
  • set the background color for the box
  • set the height for feature and article box
  • add margin to the top and bottom of each box.
<!DOCTYPE html PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD XHTML 1.0 Strict//EN"
"https://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-strict.dtd">
<html>
    <head>
    <title> 960 grid system </title>
    <link href = "CHAPTER15.14.css"
          rel  = "stylesheet"
          type = "text/css"/>
    <link href = "../CHAPTER_15/960-Grid-System-master/code/css/960_12_col.css"
           rel = "stylesheet"
          type = "text/css"/>
    </head>
    <body> 
        <div class = "container_12 clearfix ">
            <h1> Logo </h1>
            <div id = "header" class = "grid_12">
                 <div id = "nav">
                    <ul> 
                        <li><a href = ""> Home </a></li>
                        <li><a href = ""> Products </a></li>
                        <li><a href = ""> Service </a></li>
                        <li><a href = ""> About </a></li>
                        <li><a href = ""> Contact </a></li>
                    </ul>
                </div>
            </div>
        <div id = "feature" class = "grid_12">
            <p> Feature </p>
        </div>
        <div class = "Article grid_4">
            <p> Column One </p>
        </div>
        <div class = "Article grid_4">
            <p> Column Two </p>
        </div>
        <div class = "Article grid_4">
            <p> Column three </p>
        </div>
        <div class = "footer grid_12">
            <p> &copy; Copyright 2011 </p>
        </div>
        </div>
    </body>
</html>

body 
{
    text-align: center;
}
#header 
{
    background-color: antiquewhite;
}
li 
{
    display: inline;
    padding: 10px;
}
li > a 
{
    text-decoration: none;
    color: black;
}
#nav 
{
    background-color: antiquewhite;
}
#feature 
{
    background-color: antiquewhite;
    margin-top: 10px;
    height: 100px;
    padding-top: 20px;
}
.Article 
{
    background-color: antiquewhite;
    margin-top: 10px;
}
.footer 
{
    background-color: antiquewhite;
    margin-top: 10px;
}

Multiple Style Sheets

@import

Some web page author split their CSS style rule into separate stylesheet. For example they use one stylesheet to control the layout and one another to control the font color.

Some author even take more modular approach to stylesheet. Creating different stylesheet to control typography , layout , form tables and even style different each section of the site.

There are two different way to include multiple stylesheet to the page:

  1. In your HTML code there are a single <link> element that link to the stylesheet and that stylesheet we can use the @import rule to include multiple stylesheet file.
  1. In your HTML code you can use the <link> element that link to each of the style sheet( which is multiple stylesheet ).

This example on this page use the <link> element to link to the stylesheet which is style.css and in that stylesheet we use the @import rule to include multiple stylesheet in your style.css which is typography.css and table.css .

Remember whenever you use the @import rule in the stylesheet place the @import rule before any other rule in the stylesheet.

<!DOCTYPE html PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD XHTML 1.0 Strict//EN"
"https://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-strict.dtd">
<html>
    <head>
        <title> @Import rule </title>
        <link href = "CHAPTER15.15.css"
              rel  = "stylesheet"
              type = "text/css"/>
    </head>
    <body>
        <div class = "container_12 maincontent clearfix">
            <h1> Central Park Bike Hire </h1>
            <h2> Rent a bicycle to ride around Central Park: </h2>
            <table>
                <tr>
                    <th> </th>
                    <th> Per hour </th>
                    <th> Per day  </th>
                </tr>
                <tr>
                    <td> Cruiser </td>
                    <td> $9 </td>
                    <td> $45 </td>
                </tr>
                <tr>
                    <td> 21 Speed </td>
                    <td> $15 </td>
                    <td> $50 </td>
                </tr>
            </table>
            <h1 style = "letter-spacing: 0.3em;"> WHERE AND WHEN </h1>
            <hr />
            <p style = "color: blue"> Loeb Boathouse </h2>
            <p> From April to November Bicycles are available on first serve basis for riding in Central Park. </p>
            <h1 style = "letter-spacing: 0.3em;"> DEPOSITS</h1>
            <hr />
            <p style = "color: blue;"> Cash or credit card </p>
            <p> A $200 deposit is required for the hire of any of our bicycles </p>

        </div>
    </body>
</html>
@import url("table.css");
@import url("typography.css");
@import url("../CHAPTER_15/960-Grid-System-master/code/css/960_12_col.css");
body 
{
    background-color: bisque;
    margin-left: auto;
    font-size: 10px;
}
div.maincontent
{
    background-color:azure;
    border: solid red;
    margin-left: auto;
    margin-right: auto;
    height:  400px;
    padding: inherit;
}

Multiple Stylesheet

link

In this page you can see other technique to include multiple stylesheet in the <head> element is a separate <link> element for each stylesheet.

The content of the site.css is identical the same as the style.css except the code does not contain a @import rule .

As with the stylesheet if two rule applied to the same element the latter the rule appear latter in the <link> element will applied to that element and the @import will never win the precedence over the <link> even it appear latter after the <link> element.

In this example on this page the rule in the typograpy.css will take the precedence over the site.css and that because the typograpy.css appear in the latter meaning that the rule in typograpy.css is appear after the other rule.


<!DOCTYPE html PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD XHTML 1.0 Strict//EN"
"https://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-strict.dtd">
<html>
    <head>
        <title> Link  </title>
        <link href = "table.css"
              rel  = "stylesheet"
              type = "text/css"/>
        <link href = "typography.css"
              rel  = "stylesheet"
              type = "text/css"/>
        <link href = "../CHAPTER_15/960-Grid-System-master/code/css/960_12_col.css"
              rel  = "stylesheet"
              type = "text/css"/>
        <link href = "CHAPTER15.16.css"
              rel  = "stylesheet"
              type = "text/css"/>
    </head>
    <body>
        <div class = "container_12 maincontent clearfix">
            <h1> Central Park Bike Hire </h1>
            <h2> Rent a bicycle to ride around Central Park: </h2>
            <table>
                <tr>
                    <th> </th>
                    <th> Per hour </th>
                    <th> Per day  </th>
                </tr>
                <tr>
                    <td> Cruiser </td>
                    <td> $9 </td>
                    <td> $45 </td>
                </tr>
                <tr>
                    <td> 21 Speed </td>
                    <td> $15 </td>
                    <td> $50 </td>
                </tr>
            </table>
            <h1 style = "letter-spacing: 0.3em;"> WHERE AND WHEN </h1>
            <hr />
            <p style = "color: blue"> Loeb Boathouse </h2>
            <p> From April to November Bicycles are available on first serve basis for riding in Central Park. </p>
            <h1 style = "letter-spacing: 0.3em;"> DEPOSITS</h1>
            <hr />
            <p style = "color: blue;"> Cash or credit card </p>
            <p> A $200 deposit is required for the hire of any of our bicycles </p>

        </div>
    </body>
</html>
body 
{
    background-color: bisque;
    margin-left: auto;
    font-size: 10px;
}
div.maincontent
{
    background-color:azure;
    border: solid red;
    margin-left: auto;
    margin-right: auto;
    height:  400px;
    padding: inherit;
}

Example Layout

This example demonstrates a modern magazine-style layout using the 960.gs grid. Using this style sheet saves us from having to create all of the CSS code ourselves.

Several classes from the 960.gs grid style sheet have been added to code to indicate how many column of the grid each element should stretch across As you saw in this chapter. 960.gs stylesheet uses the float property to position the block next to each other.

At the start of the page. the header uses fixed positioning ( meaning that it does not move when users scrolls down the page ). The z-index property is added to the header to keep it on top of the remaining content as the users scrolls down the page.

both the header and footer are contain within <div> element which stretch the entire width of the page. inside those container element sit other element that use classes from the 960.gs style sheet to ensure that the items in the header and footer align with the rest of the content.

The feature article take up the entire width of the page. The push_7 and push_9 classes are part of the 960.gs style sheet and are used in the feature article to move the header and the content for this article over to the right.

Under the main article you can see four block. each of which is 3 column wide. These contain images followed by links to more articles

This example also uses background images to create a textured background for the page and header and also to contain the images for the feature article. Yo will learn more about these in the next chapter .

Please note if you view this example in Internet Explorer 6. the Transparent PNGs used in this design may have gray background to learn more about this issue, visit the website accompany this book where you can find a simple JavaScript and fixed this problem.

<!DOCTYPE html PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD XHTML 1.0 Strict//EN"
"https://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-strict.dtd">
<html>
    <head>
        <title> Example Layout </title>
        <link href = "CHAPTERX.css"
              rel  = "stylesheet"
              type = "text/css"/>
        <link href = "../CHAPTER_15/960-Grid-System-master/code/css/960_12_col.css"
              rel  = "stylesheet"
              type = "text/css"/>
    </head>

    <body>
<div class = "header">
    <div class = "container_12 clearfix">
        <div id = "header0" class = "grid_12">
                <div class = "header1 grid_5">
                    <h1> PEDAL FASTER </h1> 
                </div>
            <div class = "nav grid_6">
                    <ul>
                        <li><a href=""> home / </a></li>
                        <li><a href=""> news / </a></li>
                        <li><a href="">  archives /  </a></li>
                        <li><a href=""> about / </a></li>
                        <li><a href="">  contact </a></li>
                    </ul>       
            </div>
        </div>
    </div>
</div>
<div class = "wrapper">
    <div class = "container_12 clearfix">
        <div id = "mainwrapper" class = "grid_12">
            <div id = "mainheader" class = "push_7 grid_5">
                <h1><a href = ""> Fixed Gear Forever </a></h1>
            </div>
            <div id = "date" class = "push_4 grid_2">
                <p> 16 April 2011 </p>
            </div>
            <div id = "paragraphgaming" class = "push_2 grid_3">
                <p> The veloheld combines minimalist design 
                    with superb quality. Devoid of excessive graphic and 
                    gear shift components, the veloheld product range 
                    delights us with its beauty and simplicity.
                    The black and white ( yin and yang?) bicycles feature 
                    a short wheelbase a single gear and a narrow handlebar... All 
                    you need to explore the city streets.
                </p>
                <p> 
                    For those who want to create their bike themselves, the 
                    veloheld frames come in three sizes and two colours 
                    and are the perfext starting point.
                    <a href =""> Continue reading... </a>
                </p>
            </div>
        </div>
    </div>
</div>

.header 
{
    background-color: antiquewhite;
    position: fixed;
    width: 100%;
    z-index: 10;
}
body 
{
    margin-top: 0px;
    background-color:bisque;
    font-family: monospace;
}
.nav 
{
   margin-top: 10px;
}
li > a 
{
    text-decoration: none;
    color: black;
}
li 
{
    display: inline;
    margin: 10px;
}
.header1 , .nav 
{
    position: relative;
    z-index: 5;
}
li > a:hover 
{
    color:orangered;
}
#mainheader 
{
    position: relative;
    top: 100px;
}
#mainheader h1 a
{
    letter-spacing: 0.1em;
    text-decoration: none;
    color: black;
    text-transform: uppercase;
}
#date 
{
    position: relative;
    top: 150px;
    margin-top: 20px;
}
#paragraphgaming 
{
    position:relative;
    top: 200px;
    font-family: serif;
    font-weight: bold;
}
#paragraphgaming a 
{
    text-decoration: none;
    color:brown;
}
#mainarticle
{
    position: relative;
    top: 200px;
}
hr
{
    border: thin solid white;
} 
#articleheader 
{
    position: relative;
    top: 200px;
}
#articleheader h1 
{
    text-transform: uppercase;
    letter-spacing: 0.1em;
}
#morearticle
{
    position: relative;
    top: 250px;
    right: 320px;
}

{
    border: 0.5 solid white;
}

{

    left: 550px;
    top: 77px;
